title: brexit deal theresa may opinion james forsyth
story: That evening, MPs will vote on a series of Brexit amendments designed to show the EU what kind of withdrawal agreement the Commons would accept. At least one of them needs to pass.If one does get the support of a majority of MPs, then Theresa May can go back to Brussels and say, look, this is what will get the deal through my parliament.It will strengthen her negotiating hand, make the EU engage and give her a chance of securing some changes.As one secretary of state says: “She needs to demonstrate she can carry something through.”No insiders tell me that May will only go back to Brussels “when we have a very clear set of proposals”. Butnone of these amendments can muster a majority, then the EU will just sit tight.It knows this parliament is fiercely opposed to No Deal and so isn’t concerned that the UK will actually go down that route.Instead, the EU will wait, confident that the UK will request either an extension to the Brexit process or a softening of it.So far, there are a iety of amendments down. One from the shop steward of backbench Tory MPs, Graham Brady, says the Commons will support the withdrawal agreementthe backstop is replaced by “alternative arrangements” to prevent a hard border in Ireland.Another from the Tory chairman of the Northern Ireland Select Committee, Andrew ­Murrison, seeks to time-limit the backstop. Influential cabinet ministers have also been pushing for the Government to put down its own amendment.They are confident that they are winning that argument and one will go down before Tuesday — though some in Number  still prefer to put their faith in the Murrison amendment.The signicance of a Government amendment would be that Speaker John Bercow would have no choice but to call it. One indispensable minister involved in these discussions tells me: “A Government amendment could well be a more objective exit mechanism which would allow us to ­demonstrate that this is not going to be permanent.”The outline of this amendment has, I understand, been discussed with the DUP and ministers believe that the “likelihood” is that they will support it. But one cautions that “what may seem a given one day can suddenly unravel”.No won’t be drawn on whether a Government amendment will be tabled or not. But leading cabinet ministers are confident it will be. One says: “This is the best chance of moving everyone forward together.”One option being discussed is for a series of clear tests which,met, would allow the UK to exit the backstop. The aim is to make it clear that the EU couldn’t keep the UK — or Northern Ireland — in the backstop forever.There is also, I understand, “a parallel conversation” going on about what the EU will accept in terms of changes to the backstop. If a Government-backed amendment passed the Common it would also, in the words of one source, give the Government “half a chance of stopping Cooper-Boles”.The amendment from Labour’s Yvette ­Cooper and former Tory minister Nick Boles would require the Government to ask for an extension to Article  to avoid No Dealthe UK and the EU can’t come to an agreement.As this source points out: “Cooper-Boles does best when people think there isn’t an alternative.” There is no guarantee that a Government amendment will carry the day.“To pull this off, you need the ERGto come in behind it — and that’s quite a big ask,” says one of those intimately involved in these discussions.This source warns that “emotionally a lot of them will find it very dficult”. But these Brexiteer MPs need to realise thatnothing passes on Tuesday, then parliamentary efforts to extend Article  will gather more support.Brexit itself will be in danger and this country will end up with a super soft Andrex Brexit — or no Brexit at all.MPs should not do anything to suggest that they want to take No Deal off the table. This week, the EU and the Irish government have been all over the place about what No Deal would mean for the Irish border.The contradiction at the heart of the backstop is beginning to become apparent. It is, the EU and ­Ireland say, necessary to prevent a hard border. Butthe backstop results in there being No Deal, then it will lead to precisely what it is meant to avoid: A hard border.As this inconsistency becomes more and more obvious, there is more chance of member states pressing the EU to move on this issue.One minister who has been talking to his ­counterparts across the EU in the last few days tells me: “They’re ­definitely budging.”So, this would be precisely the wrong moment for MPs to undermine May’s negotiating position by talking about taking No Deal off the table. As one of those close to the PM puts it: “This has been a dficult week for the EU. Don’t make it easy for them.”This is one of the reasons why MPs MUST REJECT the Yvette Cooper amendment. At the moment, this amendment looks like it will probably pass. But given how many Labour MPs in leave-voting seats have qualms about it, this is far from certain.Tory MPs, let alone ministers, shouldn’t help it through as doing so would pull the rug from under the UK’s negotiating position.VENEZUELA is a sorry tale of where state socialism leads. In an oil-rich country, people are starving. It is embarrassing, and shaming, that Jeremy Corbyn’s ideological blinders mean that he can’t see what is happening there.Labour talk about opposing “outside interference” in Venezuela even as a slew of democracies in the region recognise the head of the national assembly, Juan Guaido, as the legitimate president.Labour’s opposition to outside interference puts them in the same position as Russia, China, Turkey, Bolivia and Cuba. This is the company we’d be keepingCorbyn became Prime Minister.AT Cabinet this week, Theresa May told ministers that to get the deal through she would have to go to the Commons and “present a changed backstop”.This is signicant because it is her recognising that she needs substantive – not just cosmetic – changes to the backstopshe is to get her deal through.TALK of an early election just won’t go away at Westminster. It is not that the Tories want one, but that there is a sense that the Commons is so deadlocked on Brexit that it might end up as the only option.One possible route to an election is that Yvette Cooper’s plan to extend Article  passes the Commons, a deal is then eventually agreed but can only pass with the rider that there is a second referendum. I understand that, in these circumstances, the Government would rather go for an early election.One senior Cabinet Minister says that Theresa May’s “reddest of red lines is we have to leave the EU”. A ­referendum with Remain on the ballot paper would threaten that.“Political parties ought to make sure they are ready to fight an ­election”, a member of the Tory party board tells me as he explains why they are rapidly stepping up candidate selection and the like. But I am told that “no one is planning an election”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chavez socialist experiment venezuela opinion
story: GDP growth will stall. Taxes will rise. We’ll even run out of Mars bars.But across the Atlantic, something has been ­happening that should give us all some perspective.Over the past decade, Venezuela has plunged into the abyss — but there’s been no civil war, no earthquakes or hurricanes.Just a brutal, corrupt government that has turned what was once Latin America’s richest country into a hellhole.Starvation rations plunged millions into hunger and ­malnutrition, with some resorting to eating dogs, cats, even zoo animals.People got into kne fights over the right to scavenge from a dumpster.Its economy is more than three times smaller than in . Inflation climbed into the thousands, then millions of per cent.The result has been a refugee crisis on the scale of the Syria conflict.No wonder tens of ­thousands of people took to the streets of the capital Caracas this week, declaring national assembly head Juan Guaido the legitimate president.All this is awful for the poor bloody Venezuelans.But what does it have to do with Britain The answer is that Venezuela wasn’t just a ­disaster. It was an experiment — cheered on by Jeremy Corbyn and his cronies.In , Hugo Chavez took over Venezuela.He ruled until his death in , when he was succeeded by his hand-picked protege Nicolas Maduro.Chavez modelled himself on Latin American ­revolutionaries like Fidel Castro and Simon Boli. He nationalised much of the oil industry — which dominates the ­Venezuelan economy — and imposed punitive taxes on foreign firms.He introduced price controls and later currency controls. He declared “economic war” on the “stateless ­bourgeoisie” and seized the goods of private companies he denounced as saboteurs.For Corbyn, the Chavez regime was an inspiration — a chance to see true socialism brought to le.Venezuela, Corbyn has said, “showed us that there is a dferent, and a better, way of doing things. It’s called socialism”.It wasn’t just Corbyn. Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell, Shadow Home Secretary Diane Abbott and Corbyn’s media chief Seumas Milne have all praised the ­Venezuelan revolution.That “better way of doing things” has ruined tens of millions of lives but there has not been a hint of an apology from Corbyn.Normally, the fact that people are taking to the streets to free themselves of a vicious regime would be cheered to the rafters by the Left.Instead, there is the silence of those who find themselves ­hideously embarrassed.The few who are not ­staring at their shoes claim that Venezuela has been the ­victim of an American plot.That Maduro took, in McDonnell’s words, a “wrong turn” from Chavez’s true socialism.That it was all down to a falling oil price.Yes, Maduro took a wrong turn. But that turn was to follow the path laid out by Chavez.From the Soviet Union to Cuba to Venezuela, there is a long and shabby history of British left-wingers acclaiming a workers’ paradise — only to declare, once its ­failure is clear, that it wasn’t really socialist after all.Never mind the millions of lives ruined — let’s have another go!If he became Prime ­Minister, Corbyn might not succeed in turning Britain into Venezuela. But we’d be Caracas to let him try.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: remain wreckers should listen to queen
story: Her Majesty is right that MPs must find the common ground. But whatever compromises are made on the finer details, that “common ground” must at its core deliver on . million votes to leave the EU, and the promises made in both Tory and Labour manestos at the last election.Those trying to derail Brexit are the ones who are, as Her Majesty puts it, “losing sight of the bigger picture”. After all, it is they who are willing to rip up centuries of democratic understanding and procedure to keep us locked within the European Union.So terried of Britain flourishing, free from Brussels’ dead hand, that they will happily destroy public trust in Parliament in order to succeed.We wish they shared Her Majesty’s obvious confidence in her country.As MPsto their constituencies this weekend, they will hear the same thing over and over again: deliver what we voted for.Those still hoping to delay Article  or even for a second referendum MUST realise the stakes.MARCH th should be a momentous day, our first outside the European Union. And it should also be the day the Prime Minister fires her hapless Chancellor Philip Hammond.Free to set our own course again, we can create the world’s most competitive economy — with lower taxes and business-friendly regulation that allows our brightest companies to prosper here and across the world.Our Eeyore Chancellor is about as far away from the dynamism we need as it is possible to imagine. At a time when we need to put energy into the economy, Hammond is human chloroform.And that’s before we get on to his outrageous disloyalty in Davos this week.The clock is ticking.JUST as most serious European leaders are thinking of creative ways to stay close to the UK after we leave, Leo Varadkar and Emmanuel Macron show just how hopeless they both are.That France’s Macron — a Poundshop Napoleon without the self-doubt — dares to lecture us when he’s got riots on the streets and approval ratings to match his stature really is quite something.Meanwhile Ireland’s Leo, who never knowingly turns down the opportunity to insert his foot squarely into his mouth, threatened that he would send the Army to the border yesterday before being forced into a screeching U-turn.And they say we’re the problem…Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: michael gove promotes explosive fertiliser
story: The Environment Secretary surprised the agriculture world by announcing the swap as part of a drive to cut air pollution.He wants producers to stop spreading urea-based feed on their crops and use ammonium nitrate, which has lower emissions.But the substance is highly controlled – and even banned in some countries – after being used in several atrocities around the world.Ammonium nitrate was used in the  Oklahoma blast which killed  peoople and the  Mumbai train bombing in which claimed  lives.It was also the explosive of choice for IRA terrorists during the Troubles which led to restrictions on sales in the UK and an outright ban in Northern Ireland.The Government’s National Counter Terrorism Security Office website states: “The blending, storage, transport and use of fertilisers is commonplace this creates opportunities for terrorist to acquire such material.”Despite this warning, Gove wants farmers to use more ammonium nitrate to help cut the cost of air pollution by £.billion a year by .The move was a “key measure” in the Clean Air Strategy published last week.Labour MPs expressed surprise that the “crazy” idea escaped being vetoed by the Home Office or  Downing Street.Farmers would also be required to keep stocks in extra-secure conditions, increasing storage costs.Shadow Cabinet office minister Chris Matheson said: “If there’s a threat of terrorism, we don’t want to be handing our adversaries an easy win.“Government departments need to be talking to each other to make sure we aren’t making their lives easier.”Labour MP Kerry McCarthy, who sits on the Commons environment committee, said: “This all reeks of a minister trying to grab a quick headline without doing the groundwork first.“This has all been rushed through to give the impression they are doing something to tackle air pollution. In fact, they are tinkering at the margins with farm fertilisers and log fires instead of making the big decisions that are needed.”Mr Gove’s spokesman said last night: “Ammonium nitrate has been used in fertilisers for years. It is better for air quality as it emits less ammonia,  per cent of which comes from farming.“Labour must think they know better than the World Health Organisation, which praised our plans as ‘an example for the rest of the world to follow’.“Labour should apologise for the harm to health caused by their dash to diesel, which has directly led to breaches in air pollution limits. We’re spending £.billion to clean up their mess.”A Tory source confirmed the Home Office had cleared Mr Gove’s proposals and added: “The biggest threat to our national security is the terrorists’ friend Jeremy Corbyn.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british twins different dads fertility treatment
story: Alexandra and Calder were born to London couple Simon and Graeme Berney-Edwards via surrogate mum Meg Stone after a £, IVF procedure.Graeme is the father of Calder and Simon is the father to Alexandra.The toddlers are twins because half of the embryos were fertilised with Graemes sperm and the other half were fertilised with SimonsThat made it possible for the fraternal twins to be born with to the two dferent fathers.Simon, , told the Mirror: “It is amazing that Graeme and I have been able to father one of our twins each.“Meg did an amazing job – and it meant she was actually pregnant by two men at the same time. It’s thanks to the wonder of IVF that we have been able to achieve our dream.“Graeme and I have always wanted to have a family and now we have our lovely twins.”The couple had to fly out to the US to complete the groundbreaking treatment because it is not practised in the UK.They met mother-of-two Meg, , from Canada, online.An anonymous woman provided her eggs, Simon and Graeme fertilised them in Los Angeles, they were frozen and then six months later the embryos were implanted into Megs womb.Simon said: We couldn’t decide on who would be the biological father. Graeme said it should be me, but I said that he had just as much right as I did.“Then the clinic told us it could be both of us. They said that we could have half the embryos fertilised with my sperm and then half with Graeme’s sperm.We were nervous at first, but meeting Meg was like being reunited with a long-lost sister. She wrapped us both in a hug before introducing us to her adorable boys.The pair were over the moon when Meg revealed she was pregnant with twins.Meg went into labour in week  of the pregnancy and Simon and Graeme were at her side.Simon said: Graeme held her hand through it all while her mum and I stood at the other end.“It was the most amazing experience of our lives. Alexandra was born first and Calder arrived minutes later. It was just amazing to meet them at last.“When we held them the first time, we couldn’t believe that we were both daddies. It was a long way to go and do this, but it was worth it to both be able to have fathered one of the twins each.The flew home seven weeks later with the twins.Meg said: I saw Simon and Graeme’s profile on a surrogacy website and I thought they had lovely smiles. I had recently split with my partner and I wasn’t ready for another baby, so I wanted to help someone.Simon and Graeme are like brothers to me now. They call me the twins’ Tummy Mummy, which I love.“It was amazing being pregnant with embryos that they had both fathered. Science is an amazing thing.”

title: karren brady influencers dont see kids friends cash
story: Weirdly, for those of us who grew up before the internet took off, that’s an actual job now.And who can blame people for ­saying: “‘Yes please” to money for doing not very much But there is something wrongInstagram users aren’t aware the ­celebrities they follow are being paid thousands of pounds — or even hundreds of thousands — to promote the products they are “recommending”.Advertisers know Instagram — which has a BILLION monthly users posting some million photos a day — is an incredibly powerful way of reaching young people.The more followers a star has, the greater their selling power.Kylie Jenner, who has million ­followers, is paid a whopping £, for every sponsored post.Under the  UK Consumer Protection From Unfair Trading regulations, ­celebrities paid to plug products are supposed to make that clear.But there are no simple guidelines.So while some celebs might say “sponsored” or “#ad” on a post, others are less open about it.That is why the Competition  ­Markets Authority conducted an ­investigation.And this week  British celebrities and “influencers” were found to have failed to follow consumer protection guidelines.They include singers Rita Ora and Ellie Goulding, models Alexa Chung and Rosie Huntington-Whiteley and video blogger Zoella.While all agreed to change their ways, none was taken to court where they might have faced fines or even jail time.“Influencers” might say the clue is in the name. They are paid to inspire you to buy stuff.Most insist they only endorse ­products they actually believe in — and we’d all hope they take their responsibility seriously.But it is easy to see how an offer of, say, £, to endorse something they “sort of” believe in might make it harder to hang on to those principles.Equally,guidelines aren’t strictly enforced, you can understand the temptation to convey the impression that you just happen to really like a particular laxative herbal tea, say, or a moisturiser that gives you a “glow”.It’s a grey area. And you might ask why it matters.But given recent news about the ­negative impact social media can have on the mental health of young people — and young women in particular — regulation of this brave new world affects us all.I need only point to another big story this week.Schoolgirl Molly Russell was  when she took her own le after showing “no obvious signs” of severe mental health issues.Her family later found she had been viewing material on social media linked to anxiety, depression, self-harm and suicide.Her father even went as far as accusing Instagram of “helping to kill her”.Social media makes it so easy to tap into someone’s daily le, their home-decor proclivities and their innermost thoughts.The intimate nature of Instagram lets you feel like these influencers are your friends, and the products they rave about their personal ­recommendations, not the outcome of a business deal.This is a real problem. But the mistake is much harder to makeadverts are clearly labelled as such.Part of the problem is how obsessed with celebrities our young people have become.When I was growing up, my main influenceswere my parents and my friends.Now, young people are influenced by people they will never meet.Some of these people, dare I say it, are talentless nobodies.You might argue you would have to be naive not to realise they are selling you something.Perhaps young people are not as cynical as the likes of me.And that is why regulation is key.IT’S hard to sympathise with Fungi, a “star” of hit telly documentary Benefits Street, who says universal credit is “the worst thing in the world”.Tracked down by this paper, James Clarkeclaimed his monthly payments had been more than halved and the all-in-one benefit was causing “hell” for him and others like him . . . because their booze budget has been cut.Fungi was claiming £ a month to spend on food and sundries. But this was slashed to £ – which doesn’t cover the £ a month he and his partner spend on strong cider.His rent, meanwhile, is paid in full via a separate taxpayer-funded handout.Fungi also says his drinking habit means he can’t work. Sorry, what Here’s another way of looking at it. People who work for eight hours a day don’t have the time to down three litres of cider a day.If Mr Clarke got a job, he might recover some of his self-esteem – and probably save his le in the process.Just to be clear – I BELIEVE in the benefits system.But it was invented to help people get back on their feet, to help those who can’t help themselves because of illness or disability.It should be a short-term measure, not a lestyle choice.In the meantime, the rest of us go to work to pay for this man’s rent and booze.All because he can’t be bothered to sort himself out.No wonder people get angry.In fact, I suspect most readers will have steam coming out of their ears.This man must start taking responsibility for himself.I SUPPOSE it was worth a shot for Diane Abbott to complain that Fiona Bruce was “badly briefed” and that her treatment as a list on Question Time was racist.But she can’t blame Fiona for her own incompetence in answering questions – and not just on Question Time.There are so many car-crash interviews to choose from . . . although the one in which Diane suggested police officers could be paid £ a year springs to mind.WHAT a nasty piece of work Dancing On Ice judge Jason Gardiner seems.We expect the judges to give feedback.And we know it won’t all be good.But his comment to Gemma Collins last week – “We are not going to see big lts from you” – came across as body-shaming.Because his real point is that she is overweight, right It’s shocking, really. I’m surprised ITV allowed it.THE secret behind Elle Macpherson’s phenomenal bod has been revealed.In an interview, she said it all comes down to . . . late breakfasts.Hmmm. No matter when we eat breakfast, most of us will never come close to looking how she does at .Actually, forget breakfast times. What struck me is her diet seems to contain just FIVE ingredients . . . one of which is nut cheese.And the only liquid is water.Elle looks great.But by God, she must be miserable.THE Premier League’s popularity continues to soar, as a study into attendances across Europe proves.And I was immensely proud to see West Ham ranked seventh by attendance in all of Europe last year.We are up there with the Continent’s elite, in a table headed by Barcelona.And that will only get better now the capacity of the London Stadium is up to , – adding to the incredible support we get from what I believe are the league’s best fans.This week, accountancy firm EY published a report on the impact the Premier League has on our economy.It generates £.billion a year in tax for the Exchequer, supporting , jobs and contributing £.billion overall to the country’s GDP.Last season, Premier League players paid more than £billion in taxes.But never mind the money.It’s still the best league in the world.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no delaying halting brexit john mann
story: Across the country people who voted dferent ways in the Brexit referendum are ­becoming bored and irritated by the silly games at Westminster.The truth is that a large majority of MPs are Remainers in their hearts and souls and are struggling to bring themselves to recognise the reality of the situation.It was us MPs who voted to give you, the people, the say on leaving or remaining in the European Union.And you voted, in higher numbers than you have ever bothered voting for any of us. Yet the same MPs who gave you a say are coming up with every excuse for why your views should not be listened to.Of course there are Remainer MPs whose constituencies voted heavily to remain.There are MPs with, I have to say it, courage, who have always argued strongly in a way that they have always known is dferent to their ­voters. These people are ­consistent and have my respect.But there are just as many who are in danger now of sitting on the fence until rigor mortis sets in, coming up with process rather than substance.They are simply hoping that others will do the dirty deed and respect the will of the people.It is also, for every Labour and Conservative MP, the manesto ­promise that we stood on at the last election. We voted for a referendum. We promised to respect the result.We got re-elected promising the same, yet Parliament continues to sit on the roundabout to nowhere.It is time to stop the shenanigans and work across the political ide to bring our country and our people together.At stake is our democracy. And in a democracy the winner prevails.Of course, in future years, people can argue that we have got it wrong and that people are entitled to change their mind. But for democracy to be true and real, we have to deliver the mandate we have been given and leave the EU on March .The referendum ided people and families, with lots of strong and dfering views. But in cherishing our democracy, we now need to come together to deliver a Brexit that respects the people’s vote and helps heal that ide.In le we have to compromise. We all have our own perfect Brexit, me included. And with ten of my colleagues we have forced through a big part of that, guaranteeing in law workers’ rights, health and safety and environmental standards. We will be competing with Europe by being the best, not by being the cheapest.I would love to have been a fly on the wall when Theresa May told union bosses that she was meeting their key demands not just with a promise but with a legal guarantee. But then she knew it was only right, because union members were the bedrock of leave voters across the country.And, I believe, we can get more in the next fortnight. A clear commitment to a once-in-a-generation investment into the Leave-voting areas that have long been starved of our fair shares — those former coal, iron and steel industrial heartlands, the unfashionable places, the areas still manufacturing. I think, as well, that union bosses and industrialists can be brought to act as advisers to the trade negotiations when we have left the EU, bringing their expertise into play to ensure a jobs-first Brexit for Britain.A country, proud and independent, standing on its own two feet, ­confident again in our democracy, bold enough to compete by being the best, British workers making high- quality products and delivering high-quality services.A country that says it will be the best by having better pay, conditions and a healthier environment than anyone  in Europe or worldwide.Is that not something to be confident in voting for, my fellow MPs  Let’s get on with it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gangsters hang puppy initiation ceremony
story: The pit bull, now named Avery, was spray painted, had her eyes burned with an unknown chemical and was beaten so badly that she was barely hanging on to le.Avery was found next to another dog in an alleyway which had already sadly died in Los Angeles, Calornia.Her brain swelled from the abuse, triggering seizures and was rushed to an animal shelter when she was found by authorities.Ellie Roberto, director of the Animal Hope and Wellness Foundation who was called to recover the dog, told Local  News: “She had clearly been beaten and spray painted and had a lot of injuries.“The other dog, unfortunately, was not found alive.”Avery continued to suffer seizures even after she was taken to McGrath Veterinary Center.Brian McGrath, the veterinarian who treated her, said: “When she came, she had an electrical cord around her neck that they were using to basically try and hang her.“So she has lacerations on her neck and some damage to her esophagus and throat.”The vet was able to alleviate Avery’s brain swelling, which stopped the seizures and made it possible to start treating her other injuries.He said: “Her main problem was head trauma from the beating, lack of oxygen to the brain, which was from strangulation.“To know a person could do that to an animal is obviously disheartening to the entire human race.”Avery had open sores on her belly and leg, a large sore on her forehead and a hole in her paw, according to the Animal Hope and Wellness Foundation.She was also severely underweight and suffering from a skin condition called mange.Marc Ching, founder of the Animal Hope and Wellness Foundation said he believes the puppy was attacked as part of a gang initiation.Avery’s abuse has been reported to law enforcement and she will go into foster care when she leaves the hospital.The battered puppy is said to have started trusting her caretakers and she will be put up for adoption once her hair grows back.The Animal Hope and Wellness Foundation is currently taking donations here.

title: emiliano sala news plane cardiff search resumes lionel messi
story: The athletes agency Sport Cover this morning confirmed two Guernsey based fishing vessels are working in the area where the plane last had radar contact.The private search comes after authorities officially called off their own hunt for Sala, , and his Brit pilot Dave Ibbotson on Thursday.Todays hunt is being supported by a huge fundraising effort that has seen Lionel Messi and a host of football stars raise more than £,.A statement on the GoFundMe page read: The call for funds launched late Friday afternoon allowed the relatives of Emiliano Sala, via a specialised organisation, to resume research in the Channel early Saturday morning. Two boats conduct the operations.More than , sq-ft of land and sea had been scoured by search and rescue teams after the Argentine ace’s small private plane went missing over the Channel on Monday.He was flying from Nantes, western France, to Cardf after making a club-record £million transfer to the Premier League strugglers.Manchester Citys Ilkay Gundogan, Nantes manager Vahid Halilhodzic, Leicester City winger Demarai Gray and Bayern Munichs Corentin Tolisso have all contributed to the donation page.It was set up by Salas French football agency, Sport Cover, while a petition launched in France has gathered more than , signatures.Argentine footie legends Messi and Diego Maradona are among those who have made public pleas for the search to be restarted.The countrys president Mauricio Macri also told his foreign minister to issue formal requests to Britain and France for search efforts to be resumed, according to a statement from the premiers office on Friday.Three planes and five helicopters racked up  hours combined flying time looking for the plane, working alongside two leboats and other passing ships.Guernseys harbour master explained a dficult decision was made to call off the mission, saying the chances of survival were extremely remote.Sala’s sister Romina made a heartfelt plea for the search to start up again as she broke down in tears outside Cardf City’s stadium.She said: We really are thankful for the support of all the players in the way they have said that we should not stop our efforts.We will find a way to restart the search. We will find Emiliano and the pilot.He is a fighter and we feel he is still out there.He has been travelling from the age of .We know he is somewhere - we want to bring him back.Weve been in touch with people who are investigating. We are trying to best to find Emiliano because we are sure he is still here.We are very humbled by the way people are helping.Sala’s agent, Mark McKay is reported to have booked part-time pilot Mr Ibbotson to fly the plane to and from Nantes after the star pleaded to get back in time to train with his new teammates.The plane was a -year-old single engine Piper Malibu air craft with a single engine.Cardf chiefs said Sala had declined the club’s offer to take a commercial flight from Nantes after saying goodbye to teammates at the French club.Sala sent audio messages about the bumpy ride he was having as the plane hit bad weather near Guernsey.It also emerged that his flight was delayed for  hours – forcing the plane to fly through the night.Sala was flying to south Wales after saying goodbye to teammates at FC Nantes on Monday, where he earned a transfer to the Premier League with  goals in  games in Ligue  this season.The plane left Nantes at around .pm on Monday, having originally been scheduled to depart on Monday morning.The aircraft got into dficulties while crossing the English Channel and vanished at around .pm.Aviation experts have told The Sun the plane could have been brought down by a build-up of deadly ice on the wings, causing the pilot to stall.One expert said: There are reports that the footballer was texting saying the aircraft is shaking and breaking up are classic signs of icing on the wings.“The pilot is most likely wrestling with a stall at ,ft.“It is likely, though, that the aircraft hit the water in one piece otherwise debris would have quickly been found.”Salas model friend who alleged the football mafia was behind the aces disappeance has said she regrets her comments.Berenice Schkair, , said she had acted on impulse when she posted the online messages alleging: Investigate the football mafia because I don’t believe this was an accident.Berenice told an Argentinian TV programme overnight they had last spoken the day before the crash, although she insisted she was just a “good friend” and not an ex-girlfriend or his current partner as initially reported.Fighting back tears over her friends disappearance, she said: I couldn’t believe it at first and I had a bad feeling and made the mistake of tweeting what I did.I regret doing what I did now because I didn’t have any real information.I feel it was inappropriate of me to do what I did then and until Emi’s body appears I don’t think it’s the right time to be analysing anything.Whoanyone is to blame is going to be resolved by investigators. I can’t blame anyone right now.At the moment I just want to add my grain of sand to the campaign to make sure the search is resumed and everything possible is done to find Emi and the pilot.And in a message to her the missing athlete, she said: I know you’re strong. We are waiting for you.It has also emerged Cardf City are set to launch a legal bid to recoup the £million they could lose over the Sala plane disaster.Cardf now faces an initial loss of around £million, even after insurance kicks in, the Dailyreports.But club bosses are planning their next step as it is predicted they will be forced to pay out £million for a three-year contract deal, including a £.million agents’ fee.Sala’s agent McKay has also revealed that the star shared jokey texts with his son Jack, who is also a Cardf player, while they discussed his flight arrangements, reports the BBC.Jack apparently told his new teammate his dad would arrange the flight “for freeit helped him score goals”.The men then discussed the dficulty of flying to Nantes by a commercial airline.Agent McKay added: We had no involvement in selecting a plane or a pilot and we also wish to make clear again we do not own the plane that Emiliano flew on.

title: pregnant mum sleep sofa bedroom mouldy
story: But housing association bosses have pinned the blame on condensation caused by a tumble dryer being used in an unventilated room.Pregnant Abbie Cook Dukes and her concerned mum, Joanna Dukes, spoke to Birmingham Live about the problem, which has resulted in mould-riddled furniture, a pushchair, clothing and carpets having to be thrown out.Joanna said there had been a “severe damp and mould problem” in the council house for almost four years.The grandma added: “The smell of the bedrooms is awful it hits the back of your throat. story: David Mearns, , arrived in Guernsey this morning after pals and wellwishers raised £k for a last-gasp rescue mission.The private search comes after authorities officially called off their own hunt for Sala, , and his Brit pilot Dave Ibbotson on Thursday.Mearns told reporters: The family still have some hope, theyre looking at this as a missing person, a missing plane, and until they are satisfied, thats the mode that were in.The hunt is being supported by a huge fundraising effort that has seen Lionel Messi and a host of football stars raise more than £,.Mearns will use the latest underwater technology to scan the seabed around Casquets Island - where the Argentine strikers plane went missing earlier this week.A statement on the GoFundMe page read: The call for funds launched late Friday afternoon allowed the relatives of Emiliano Sala, via a specialised organisation, to resume research in the Channel early Saturday morning. Two boats conduct the operations.More than , sq-ft of land and sea had been scoured by search and rescue teams after the Argentine ace’s small private plane went missing over the Channel on Monday.He was flying from Nantes, western France, to Cardf after making a club-record £million transfer to the Premier League strugglers.Manchester Citys Ilkay Gundogan, Nantes manager Vahid Halilhodzic, Leicester City winger Demarai Gray and Bayern Munichs Corentin Tolisso have all contributed to the donation page.It was set up by Salas French football agency, Sport Cover, while a petition launched in France has gathered more than , signatures.Argentine footie legends Messi and Diego Maradona are among those who have made public pleas for the search to be restarted.The countrys president Mauricio Macri also told his foreign minister to issue formal requests to Britain and France for search efforts to be resumed, according to a statement from the premiers office on Friday.Three planes and five helicopters racked up  hours combined flying time looking for the plane, working alongside two leboats and other passing ships.Guernseys harbour master explained a dficult decision was made to call off the mission, saying the chances of survival were extremely remote.Sala’s sister Romina made a heartfelt plea for the search to start up again as she broke down in tears outside Cardf City’s stadium.She said: We really are thankful for the support of all the players in the way they have said that we should not stop our efforts.We will find a way to restart the search. We will find Emiliano and the pilot.He is a fighter and we feel he is still out there.He has been travelling from the age of .We know he is somewhere - we want to bring him back.Weve been in touch with people who are investigating. We are trying to best to find Emiliano because we are sure he is still here.We are very humbled by the way people are helping.Sala’s agent, Mark McKay is reported to have booked part-time pilot Mr Ibbotson to fly the plane to and from Nantes after the star pleaded to get back in time to train with his new teammates.The plane was a -year-old single engine Piper Malibu air craft with a single engine.Cardf chiefs said Sala had declined the club’s offer to take a commercial flight from Nantes after saying goodbye to teammates at the French club.Sala sent audio messages about the bumpy ride he was having as the plane hit bad weather near Guernsey.It also emerged that his flight was delayed for  hours – forcing the plane to fly through the night.Sala was flying to south Wales after saying goodbye to teammates at FC Nantes on Monday, where he earned a transfer to the Premier League with  goals in  games in Ligue  this season.The plane left Nantes at around .pm on Monday, having originally been scheduled to depart on Monday morning.The aircraft got into dficulties while crossing the English Channel and vanished at around .pm.Aviation experts have told The Sun the plane could have been brought down by a build-up of deadly ice on the wings, causing the pilot to stall.One expert said: There are reports that the footballer was texting saying the aircraft is shaking and breaking up are classic signs of icing on the wings.“The pilot is most likely wrestling with a stall at ,ft.“It is likely, though, that the aircraft hit the water in one piece otherwise debris would have quickly been found.”Salas model friend who alleged the football mafia was behind the aces disappeance has said she regrets her comments.Berenice Schkair, , said she had acted on impulse when she posted the online messages alleging: Investigate the football mafia because I don’t believe this was an accident.Berenice told an Argentinian TV programme overnight they had last spoken the day before the crash, although she insisted she was just a “good friend” and not an ex-girlfriend or his current partner as initially reported.Fighting back tears over her friends disappearance, she said: I couldn’t believe it at first and I had a bad feeling and made the mistake of tweeting what I did.I regret doing what I did now because I didn’t have any real information.I feel it was inappropriate of me to do what I did then and until Emi’s body appears I don’t think it’s the right time to be analysing anything.Whoanyone is to blame is going to be resolved by investigators. I can’t blame anyone right now.At the moment I just want to add my grain of sand to the campaign to make sure the search is resumed and everything possible is done to find Emi and the pilot.And in a message to her the missing athlete, she said: I know you’re strong. We are waiting for you.It has also emerged Cardf City are set to launch a legal bid to recoup the £million they could lose over the Sala plane disaster.Cardf now faces an initial loss of around £million, even after insurance kicks in, the Dailyreports.But club bosses are planning their next step as it is predicted they will be forced to pay out £million for a three-year contract deal, including a £.million agents’ fee.Sala’s agent McKay has also revealed that the star shared jokey texts with his son Jack, who is also a Cardf player, while they discussed his flight arrangements, reports the BBC.Jack apparently told his new teammate his dad would arrange the flight “for freeit helped him score goals”.The men then discussed the dficulty of flying to Nantes by a commercial airline.Agent McKay added: We had no involvement in selecting a plane or a pilot and we also wish to make clear again we do not own the plane that Emiliano flew on.

title: speedboat jack shepherd admission pal
story: Maiko Tchanturidze, , said he made an emotional video call to her just days before he surrendered to police in Georgia.She recalled: “He said he had something to tell me. He seemed upset, his face was red.“He was struggling to get his words out, but he said he’d been involved in a boat accident where a girl had died, and that he was wanted by Interpol.“He said he was going to hand himself in because he ‘didn’t want to be hunted down like an animal’.“I was beyond shocked and by the end, he was also crying his eyes out. It was very frightening to hear his story.”Self-pitying Shepherd, , persuaded her the death of Charlotte Brown, , had not been his fault. Maiko said: “I had questions, but he answered them all and cleared even tiny doubts I had.”Charlotte, of Clacton, Essex, drowned in the Thames in December  on her first date with Shepherd.She had gone for a ride in his aging speedboat after ing from a boozy meal to his houseboat in West London.Web developer Shepherd fled the country but his Old Bailey manslaughter trial convicted him in his absence and sentenced him to six years in jail.He spent ten months on the run before surrendering to police in Georgia’s capital Tbilisi on Wednesday.In that time he was allowed to claim nearly £, in legal aid to fight an appeal. He is paying three lawyers out of his own pocket to fight extradition.Maiko, below, now working in customer service for a German company, said the pair met in a park when he petted her dog Lucy.She said: “We bumped into each other a few more times. We became close so I introduced him to my sister and friends, and we started going out to bars and restaurants.“It developed into a very close friendship. But it never went any further.“I don’t knowJack had feelings for me but as far as I was concerned, we were just good friends.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cult of brexit remainer fading
story: I will try, but it is hard to see eye to eye with those who regard the .million who voted Out in  as pig- ignorant racists.Or to forgive Chancellor Phil Hammond for twisting Treasury data to undermine the British economy.I will simply wish him well in retirement at the earliest possible moment.Anna Soubry is a bit of a challenge too, but I will ­eventually find something nice to say.As for EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier, even Her ­Eurosceptic Majesty would find little common ground with the man who vowed to punish her United Kingdom for daring to leave.But it will be cult-like Remainers who find it hardest to kiss and make up.Their hatred of Leavers has reached sectarian proportions.Astonishingly a poll found many would ban marriage outside the EU faith.Indeed, my old friendMatthew Parris insists Her Maj was wrong to suggest there is any common ground at all, because it might appear to endorse Theresa May’s dodgy deal.The Times sage has abandoned the Zen-like equilibrium which once made him ­compulsive reading. Along with the likes of megabucks Remainers Tony Blair, Peter Mandelson and PR guru Roland Rudd, he seems to think Brexiters are basically pond le.That theory should be buried forever after this weekend’s passionate plea from leading academic Sir Noel Malcolm for MPs to stop wrecking Brexit.Writing in the devoutly pro-EU Financial Times, this distinguished Fellow of All Souls, Oxford, spells out the essence of the Leave case: “Brexit is about sovereignty — and parliament must respect that.”“If the UK is now on the brink of a constitutional crisis,” he adds, “one major reason is that a signicant number of MPs still oppose any version of Brexit, and seek a second ­referendum solely for the sake of reversing the decision of the last one.”Sir Noel does not believe people voted Out because they were racist.“The most important reason was democracy,” he says.“They wanted to live under laws made by the people they elected. Immigration came second.What they objected to was a supranational government ­making some of their laws and lting all immigration controls on the inhabitants of  other countries.”Another Remainer fiction is that Brexiters are narrow-minded Little Englanders.Yet the Daily Mail found space for a German view that Brussels should stop “insulting Britain” and honour us as champions of peace in Europe.“Such blinkered and sour responses are wrong-headed,” says Alexander von Schoenburg, a senior editor of Germany’s biggest newspaper, Bild.“They ignore the great debt Germany and the whole ­Continent owes our friends across the Channel.“We must always remember that throughout your history, independence and sovereignty have been paramount.“Germany in particular should tread lightly when it comes to dealing with your proud nation. It was Great Britain that first stood up to Hitler in .And it was Britain that opened its doors to thousands of ­Jewish refugees fleeing certain death during the Holocaust.“Put simply, there would be no free Europe without you and the bloody sacrice you made to rescue the Continent.”This remarkable tribute ­follows a recent love letter to the UK from Germany’s next Chancellor calling for a friendly Brexit orce and an end to bitterness.It is now clear hardline Remainers have over-reached themselves. The worm has turned.Talk of a second referendum is dead and voters are on the warpath against MPs plotting to scupper Brexit in tomorrow’s Commons showdown.Brussels is in chaos over the Northern Ireland backstop.Michel Barnier has started muttering about new tech- nology to police post-Brexit ­frontiers — a UK idea initially dismissed as “magical thinking”.EU allies are breaking ranks to demand a decent deal — for their sake as much as ours.It is way past time now for Theresa May to scrap the backstop and tell Brussels exactly what she needs to get her deal through Parliament.“There is absolutely no truth in speculation that ­passengers are being advised not to book,” stormed Brittany Ferries as it announced plans to INCREASE services.Meanwhile, mischief-making aviation giant Airbus admits it was asked by Downing Street to warn – incredibly – that it would shut up shopBritain left without a deal.Project Fear is shameless.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brit traveller family new zealand cash 10k fame
story: Patriach Larry Doran vowed to explain the horrors weve been through after touching down at Heathrow with the rest of his family this morning.The dad claims his family were forced to flee to the mountains for two days to escape hostilities - after the Mayor of Auckland slammed them as worse than pigs.He said: We were scared for own safety and had to hide away, the five of us with a seven-month-old baby.The Maoris helped us by getting us food and water. They were our only friends there.He also claimed the car they hired was stolen - and had £, in cash inside.He hit out at Kiwi cops for doing nothing about it.He blasted: It’s a disgrace. A crime has been committed and they don’t care. Even the mayor is calling us names.People tried to intimidate us and ram us off the road when a , dollar reward was put up to anyone who could find us.They called us gipsy scum and made me crash my car setting off all the airbags. It was terrying.“That’s the type of madness we had to put up with and now we want to tell our story for the right fee.We’ve just got home but I’ve got an to agent and we’re going to sell our story. It’s good and it’s worth a lot more than £,.Our family holiday - it was me, my we, my daughter, my son and his we and the baby - has been ruined and so has our reputation.”The group of around  included brothers John and David Johnson, their partners, children, and mother, Eileen Doran, of Liverpool.In a radio interview, Auckland Mayor Phil Goff said: “Ive asked the council to follow up because I want to see them loaded with an infringement fine for trashing our country. They shouldnt even be here.”Another member of the group, , who cannot be named for legal reasons, was charged and bailed from Auckland District Court for assault with a weapon, reckless driving, and fraud by dishonestly using a document.He has been bailed until February.A member of the family, Tina Marie Cash, who is seven months pregnant, appeared in court after being arrested for thieving four cans of Red Bull from a service station.The group re-voiced a claim they made to Kiwi media outlet Newshub, that their arrival was after a lot of the offences they are accused of took place.Joe Doran – sarcastically nicknamed Honest John – resorted to dying his hair blonde to avoid being recognised during the later part of the holiday.The Dorans said they got accused of leaving rubbish on a beach which wasnt theirs.

title: uk fattest ten year old 16 stone
story: The lad weighs more than  stone, three times the average for a boy of his age.However, the mum, , insists his obesity is the result of a stress hormone disorder and not of gorging on junk food.She claims he does not eat enough and has only a sandwich for lunch and dinner.She said: “He goes without meals. He is very fussy with what food he eats.We cannot understand why he is only eating that and not losing weight.”The average ten-year old boy should weigh just under five stone, experts say.But the boy is nearly four stone heavier than the average British man.He is also Britain’s heaviest ten-year-old, weighing more than a st lb Birmingham boy assessed by researchers two years ago.The lad, from Hertfordshire, is on a reduced timetable at school because his size means he cannot manage a full day.His mum, who weighs st and has an overweight older daughter, said doctors had failed to explain his weight gain.She said her son had been active, gone swimming and boxed but his weight still went up.But the mum, who has split from the boy’s dad, said: “He does not like leaving the house.“He is not active. He has a massive germ phobia now.“Doctors don’t think it is genetic. He has been tested and nothing came back, they can’t see anything at the moment.“The only other thing is hormones. Stress hormones have not helped him.”Social services are monitoring the boy but his mum added: “It is horrible. We want to get on with le and not have the threat hanging over us.”Tam Fry, from the National Obesity Forum, said the case showed that the National Healthy Schools Programme was failing.He said: “This child has been let down. If you pick these cases up early, then it stops youngsters reaching extreme weights.”More than four million British children are classied as overweight or obese, researchers say.Social services took an overweight child from his parents in Manchester in  but say they will act onlya child is at risk of signicant harm. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: molly russell social media blame
story: Vulnerable Molly Russell faced a flood of self-harm images on Instagram and Pinterest — helping drive her to suicide.The sites haven’t done enough to stop a repeat of this tragedy.And the power of the web giants is only growing. Last week, Facebook revealed plans to merge Instagram, WhatsApp and Messenger into the world’s largest social network.Enough. We need action now.So well done Matt Hancock for threatening the nuclear option. He warns companies could be shut downthey continue to fuel a suicide epidemic.Britain must be a world leader in holding the tech Goliaths to account.No more kids should suffer Molly’s fate.MARTIAL law  Come off it.Claims that Britain will need military intervention in a No Deal Brexit are the most ridiculous fear-mongering yet.No Deal would be a challenge — but Britain would get through it and thrive.Panicked civil servants should listen to the Queen. As Her Majesty said, seeking common ground will take us far.Because evenNo Deal isn’t ideal, it must stay on the table.When Theresa May heads back to Brussels, the EU need to know we’re serious about walking awaythey don’t fix the ridiculous backstop.That’s why Yvette Cooper’s parliamentary power grab is so dangerous.If MPs delay Brexit fearing No Deal, Britain’s hand will be weaker, making a second referendum a real danger.It’s also worrying that Mrs May told allies she could never go for No Deal.Stand firm, Prime Minister — and don’t crumble to the prophets of doom.BOSSES at tax-dodging firms like Starbucks should read of Britain’s biggest taxpayers — and hang their heads in shame.Some firms will go to any s to slash their tax bills. title: screaming shoppers trapped in lift as it plunged seven floors again and again in 40 minute ordeal
story: More than a dozen people were left terried after they becoming trapped at St Davids Shopping Centre in Cardf.Those involved described the scene on Saturday night as something from a horror film as the lt travelled up and down more than  times.Their terrying experience, which is alleged to have lasted around  minutes, also left people screaming, panicking and sweating as they sat on the floor to avoid any serious injuries, they told local reporters.One young girl even had a panic attack and was left crying and shaking, while another woman described it as an absolute horric and le changing experience.Firefighters from South Wales Fire and Rescue Service were called to the scene, and a spokeswoman for St Davids has since apologised to those involved.But the trapped shoppers have slammed the centre for only giving them a bottle of water and an offer of free parking by way of apology.Four people involved in the drama included Taris Chapman, , and her friends Amy Hitchins, Wallis Owen and Olivia Oldham, who were making their way back to the car after having food at TGI Fridays.The girls, all from the Rhondda, posted about the frightening experience on Facebook, in a bid to warn others about how dangerous lts can be.Taris said: Myself, three of my friends and nine other people were in the lt in St David’s shopping centre this evening when it stopped working.This resulted in  minutes of the lt going to the top floor and just plunging us down seven floors with force, whilst jolting.Not to mention, how frightening it was as we couldn’t get hold of the of the help line  minutes into the lt breaking [down].When we did manage to get hold of them, the speaker kept cutting off and due to no signal we couldn’t even get through to the emergency services.Around  minutes later, the fire service came and helped us get out.This was the most terrying thing we have experienced and want to warn others as it was very distressing.Speaking to WalesOnline this morning, Taris and her chums said it was like something from a horror film.They said: It felt like there was no control over the lt. Everyone was screaming and panicking.It felt like the cord that holds the lt wasnt working properly.Olivia, who was already petried of lts, ended up having a panic attack and was crying and shaking throughout the ordeal.They described how the lt hit the top floor, before jolting and dropping back to the bottom - but the doors would not open.Taris and her friends also described the dficulties they faced in contacting emergency staff at the shopping centre.We couldnt get through and when we did we just couldnt understand what was being said.It was boiling in there. Everyone was sat down, panicking and sweating.We had no drinks and it felt like there was no air.Megan Jones, , and her mother Alyson Jones, , from Aberdare, were among those trapped.On Facebook, Megan, described the ordeal as an absolute horric and le changing experience.She added: Not being able to contact anyone whilst we were being thrown up and down with no way of stopping the lt was honestly the worst experience of my le.If there was any more than the  of us in there, there would have been bigger issues!She compared the horric experience to the Tower of Terror -  a Disneyland ride which includes sudden drops within a dark, enclosed space.Megan added: There were around  of us in the lt, but it says it can hold !If there were any more people, there would have been some serious injuries.We were all sat on the floor to keep safe.Steven Madeley, General Manager for St David’s said: “We can confirm there was a fault with a lt in the centre Saturday evening, and the Fire Service attended in line with our usual protocol.We’d like to apologise to those affected and thank them for their patience. We will be liaising with those customers directly.“We would like to reassure that the incident was a fault, and there was no risk or danger to those involved.A spokeswoman for South Wales Fire and Rescue Service confirmed a crew from Cardf Central were called to St Davids Shopping centre at around pm.She said: We obtained the lt keys and the people inside were released safely.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mh370 pilot deceived radar new flight simulations
story: The Malaysian Airlines jet vanished en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing on  March  - sparking one of the worlds greatest aviation mysteries.Some experts have claimed that rogue pilot Zaharie Amad Shah deliberately crashed the jet in a “suicide mission”, killing all  people on board.And now Victor Iannello, who works for the Independent Group- which is assisting Australian officials search for the missing plane – is supporting this theory.In a report that has used civilian radar data, he says that Shah may have used a particular flight path to deceive radar operators into believing the plane was planning to land at Penang Airport.Mr Iannello created a flight simulation in order to better understand the route taken.The MH flight path was plotted together with two recent Air Hong Kong flights for the route from Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam to Penang in Malaysia.Mr Iannello believes the findings prove “clearly there was no intention on the part of the pilot to actually perform the procedure and to land.”He added: “However, it is possible that by flying an element of the course reversal procedure, there was a deliberate attempt to deceive radar operators into believing that MH had an intention to land.”A  of experts supported this theory when they appeared on Australian TV programme  Minutes.They revealed evidence that suggests Shah executed a careful series of manoeuvres to evade detection and ensure the plane disappeared in a remote location.He even flew across the Malaysian and Thai borders to avoid military radar as part of his plans to ensure the Malaysia Airline flight disappeared forever.They all agreed the probability of the disappearance being an accident was one in a trillion adding Shah deliberately ditched the plane in the Indian Ocean west of Australia.Some of the experts believe the pilot even made a controlled landing on the water so it had more chance of staying intact - making it harder to find its wreckage.John Dawson, a lawyer who represented nine families from MH , recently told News Corp Australia the evidence pointed squarely to one of the aircrew being responsible.“In MH, you have the pilot flying between Malaysia and Beijing who turns back the aircraft. The evidence is so heavily weighted to involvement by one of the aircrew taking this aircraft down.“That aircraft has probably depressurised, the people died of asphyxiation, it was premeditated murder. It was highly planned. The bodies have never been found.”But despite experts’ observations, the Malaysian government, which has signed a “no cure, no fee” deal with Texas-based company Ocean Infinity to resume the hunt for the plane, remains silent on the question of Zaharie’s possible involvement.Ocean Infinity started the search on January  this year, following a failed £million search for the plane.  At the time, experts said they expected to have answers within a matter of weeks.The company has  search days to look for the plane, which has been spread over several months. Officials said there was roughly an  per cent chance of finding traces of the wreckage in a new , square mile search area.The investigation is expected to end in mid-June but those on the TV show said they feared MH may never be found.

title: junk food firms fuelling obesity
story: Experts say the firms are endangering the nation’s health by getting people hooked on food and drink that is high in fat and sugar.They want a global treaty that bans food firms from influencing government policy.It would open the door to a raft of nanny state measures, including higher taxes on meat and chocolate and an end to BOGOF deals.The food industry, which has previously opposed such measures, last night branded the demands extreme and deeply irresponsible.They said the best way to combat obesity is by government and industry working together to improve diets and nutrition.More than six in ten British adults are overweight or obese and a third of kids are too fat by the time they leave primary school.Being overweight increases the risk of heart disease, cancer and type- diabetes. It is thought to cost the NHS £billion a year.The Commission on Obesity, assembled by The Lancet medical journal, also wants higher fuel taxes to encourage people to walk.It says a treaty would “recognise the fundamental and irreconcilable conflict that exists between some food and drinks industries’ interests and those of public health”.The Lancet was mocked last week for claiming Brits should eat no more than a quarter a rasher of bacon and two-thirds of a fish finger a day.Prof William Dietz, from the Commission, said: “Although food clearly dfers from tobacco because it is a necessity to support human le, unhealthy food and beverages are not.“The similarities with Big Tobacco lie in the damage they induce and the behaviours of the corporations that profit from them.” Tim Rycroft, from trade body the Food and Drink Federation, said: “Drawing a comparison between tobacco and food is deeply irresponsible.“Food and drink are essential to sustain le while even the smallest dose of tobacco is harmful to health.“The food and drink industry has a proud record, working alongside Government, making positive changes to the nation’s diet, for over ten years.“It is widely acknowledged that obesity rates in the UK are too high, but that can’t change without the active partnership of industry.“Only those with the most extreme of viewpoints could believe that denying our industry a seat at the policymaking table would help to improve UK diets and nutrition.”The Commission calls for higher taxes on red meat so it becomes unaffordable for most people, causing them to eat less.They want higher levies on petrol and diesel, so people are less likely to drive and more likely to walk or use public transport.And they demand a ban on the advertising and promotion of food and drink high in fat and sugar to reduce awareness and affordability.The  of  experts, from  countries, also want health warnings on junk food, similar to those seen on cigarette packs.And they insist recipes for family favourites, such as cakes, biscuits and pizzas, are changed to make them lower in fat, sugar and salt.Companies that fail to comply must be fined for failing to hit targets, they add.The Lancet was mocked last week for saying Brits should eat no more than a quarter rasher of bacon a day.Other daily limits include two-thirds of a fish finger, a p-sized patty of beef and a quarter of a chicken breast.People would also be allowed   of a tin of baked beans and a tablespoon of olive oil a day amid claims such a lestyle would help save the planet.Our journalists strive for title: theresa may rule out no deal
story: The PM told members of her top team that she is not yet prepared to rule out no deal in public because it would remove a key bargaining chip in negotiations with the EU.But a Cabinet source who has sat in meetings with the PM and ministers over the last week told The Sun: “The PM has made quite clear that she’s not going to go for no deal.”Another senior Tory told The Sun that Remainer ministers have succeeded in influencing the PM to privately oppose a no deal Brexit.The source said: “She’s terried about jobs, they’ve got it into her head that there would be lots of job losses and she doesn’t want that.It’s really troubling her.”Yesterday Education Secretary Damian Hinds echoed this message, telling Sky News: “I can’t envisage a scenario that no deal becomes government policy.”And Mrs May’s de-facto PM David Lidington issued a last ditch appeal to Remainer ministers not to quit in order to back a plan to avoid a no deal Brexit in  Commons votes.Amber Rudd is among a string of ministers who have threatened to quit so they can vote in favour of ruling out no deal.But in highly signicant remarks Mr Lidington urged them to hold fire - saying they would get another chance to vote against a no deal Brexit next month.Mr Lidington wrote in the Observer: “If Parliament wishes to avoid no deal, I have no doubt it will find ways to express a view in the coming weeks.But next week’s debate is not a re-run of the meaningful vote, nor is it the final decision point for MPs.So we must keep our focus on the only real way to rule out no deal – and that is to find common ground on a deal.”Defence Minister Tobias Ellwood broke ranks and insisted publicly for the first time that a no deal scenario must be ruled out. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may tech solution irish backstop
story: He lavished praise on the “impulse” of a key proposal tabled by Tory rebels designed to unite the party.The amendment - led by the powerful  Tory committee boss Sir Graham Brady - proposes technological solutions to avoid theof a hard border with Ireland instead of tying the UK to the EU’s customs union.A growing number of Tories say they will back the PM’s dealshe succeeds with this plan - in what could give her the crucial breakthrough she needs to leave the EU on March .If it wins the backing of a majority of MPs in tomorrow’s crunch set of Commons votes, it would send the PM back to Brussels later this week with a renewed mandate to negotiate.But yesterday Ireland doubled down on its refusal to reopen the Withdrawal Agreement, which would be necessary to change the backstop plans.Ireland’s deputy PM Simon Coveney insisted the EU “will not raty a Withdrawal Agreement that doesn’t have a backstop in it,” adding: “It’s as simple as that.”“The backstop is already a compromise. It is a series of compromises.“It was designed around British red lines.But he then displayed signs Ireland has been rattled by internal EU wrangling over the backstop in recent days.He told the Andrew Marr Show: “Ireland has the same position as the European Union now, I think, when we say that the backstop as part of the Withdrawal Agreement is part of a balanced package that isn’t going to change.”On the same programme minutes later Mr Hancock suggested Mr Coveney was bluffing and denied Mrs May’s deal was “dead in the water”.The Health Secretary said: “That’s a negotiating position the Irish are taking, but I think it’s also extremely clear from that interview and the tone is that Ireland doesn’t want to have a no-deal Brexit.“The whole purpose of the backstop is to avoid a hard border, which risks being a consequence of a no-deal Brexit.‘The idea the EU and the Irish Government would drive this process to a no-deal exit in order to try to achieve something which is intended to avoid no-deal Brexit, that is not going to happen.”In a coded appeal to Tory Brexiteers to back Sir Graham’s plan to replace the backstop, Mr Hancock said his efforts at trying to find a solution were “extremely valuable”.He told ITV News: “The impulse behind those who’ve supported the Brady amendment I entirely understand and we need to look for a pragmatic solution.”And the Health boss said The clip was taken at the Olenya air base above the arctic circle and clearly shows the planes heavy impact with the runway. story: NewsBrexit: Ireland dumps cold water on Theresa Mays last big hope to pass her dealThe government is "listening very carefully" to a call to ditch the Irish backstop - but rattled Irish politician Simon Coveney claimed the EU wont accept itShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video simon-coveney-talks-andrew-marr-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIreland has dumped cold water on Theresa Mays latest last-ditch hope to pass her Brexit deal. The Republics deputy PM blasted Mrs May as it emerged shes considering backing a demand to scrap a crucial clause called the Irish backstop. The backstop is the main reason MPs defeated the -page Brexit deal by a record -vote majority this month. But now veteran MP Graham Brady is leading a group of Tories who say theyll change their mind and back the deal -the backstop is replaced with alternative arrangements. And Cabinet minister Matt Hancock has confirmed the government will listen very carefully to Sir Grahams call - whichpassed on Tuesday, would send an ultimatum to the EU to think again. But Irelands rattled Deputy PM Simon Coveney blasted the plan and claimed the EU wont accept it. “Your Prime Minister signed up to the backstop as a compromise which was designed around her and Britain’s red lines, he told the BBC.  The backstop is already a compromise. It is a series of compromises. It was designed around British red lines. Ireland has the same position as the European Union now, I think, when we say that the backstop as part of the Withdrawal Agreement is part of a balanced package that isnt going to change.”  Mr Coveney said abandoning the backstop would mean relying on an aspirational hope with no clear image of what comes next. He added: The European Parliament will not raty a Withdrawal Agreement that doesnt have a backstop in it. Its as simple as that. The backstop is an insurance policy which would kick in on  January there is still no arrangement to keep the border open between Northern Ireland and the Republic. It would prevent ato the violence of the Troubles - but the price would be trapping the UK under EU customs rules indefinitely.  Tory MP Graham Brady has laid an amendment to Theresa Mays Brexit plans, saying the government requires the Northern Ireland backstop to be replaced with alternative arrangements to avoid a hard border. The amendment by Sir Graham, chairman of the Tory backbench  Committee, is one of  being laid by MPs ahead of a vote on Tuesday. Askedthe government would back it, Health Secretary Matt Hancock told the BBC: I think we have got to listen very carefully to people who are willing to vote for the deal subject to some amendments.  And I think we need to build that majority in the Commons, clearly. And this was one of the proposals thats coming from a wide range of people who want to get a deal through and have that good future relationship. He added: “Whether it’s that exact one - we don’t know which amendments the Speaker will select and so we don’t know exactly the shape of the debate on Tuesday. “But I do understand the impulse behind those who are laying that amendment. Tory MP Andrea Jenkyns went further, demanding Theresa May bin the backstop completely. She also suggested the PM replace her chief negotiator Olly Robbins with her own husband Philip May - who reportedly urged her to keep going with her deal.  But Mr Coveney suggested binning the backstop had no chance of success in the EU. He said: There are ways of resolving these issues - in my view, by changing the aspirations in the future relationship declaration which in my view will reassure people that the backstop is never likely to be used. That is the way I hope these negotiations will go, rather than the British Parliament deciding on something that may command a majority in Westminster but has no chance of getting agreement or ratication in the EU. Ireland’s Europe Minister Helen McEntee added: To suggest that we would compromise on the Irish backstop is suggesting that we would compromise on the leading requirement ensure that we protect the peace that we’ve had for the past  years. To put a unilateral clause in a backstop, to put a time limit on the backstop, it ceases to become a backstop or it ceases to be a backstop”. Despite Irelands comments, government sources and Mr Hancock suggested there was still wriggle room around removing the current backstop - as long as it gets a smart replacement. Mr Hancock denied Mr Coveneys comments meant Theresa Mays Brexit deal was dead in the water, saying: Not at all. He added: Thats a negotiating position the Irish are taking, but I think its also extremely clear from that interview and the tone... is that Ireland doesnt want to have a no-deal Brexit. The whole purpose of the backstop is to avoid a hard border, which risks being a consequence of a no-deal Brexit. The idea the EU and the Irish Government would drive this process to a no-deal exit in order to try to achieve something which is intended to avoid no-deal Brexit, that is not going to happen. Meanwhile Labour are still considering whether to back the most likely amendment to pass on Tuesday - one that would delay the  March date of Brexit. Yvette Cooper, the MP behind the bid, said today it will be up to MPs to decide how long a delay is for. The EU would still have to sign off a delay - but in a boost to the delayers, Mr Coveney said Ireland will not be an obstacle to doing that.

Among Conservative supporters trust in Mrs May fell  points to % and among Labour backers trust in Mr Corbyn dropped  points to %.Some % of those questioned said they did not feel their views were represented in British politics, and the feeling was stronger among those who leant towards Labourthan those with Conservative sympathies . Asked which institutions were the most broken, % of us chose government, compared with just % for the media, % for business and % for NGOs .
