Surgery isn’t for everybody but I feel this will boost my confidence to meet new friends. “There should also be more services which encourage older people to mix and try dferent things rather than just playing bridge and Scrabble.” Toni will have her four-hour op at Harley Street Skin Clinic, where her daughter Josie Carter, , has already had acid face peels and laser surgery.  Celeb clients of the London clinic include Emmerdale’s Claire King, former Saturdays singer Vanessa White and Benidorm actress Sherrie Hewson. Toni, a widow who has lived alone since Josie and son Giles, , left home, began her working le at just  on a farm in southern Ireland milking cows. At  she arrived in Wales, became a nanny and did silver service waitressing. For a while she worked at the Empire Cinema in London’s Leicester Square, where she met stars at premieres. She added: “I’ve always worked really hard and now it is my time to enjoy it.” Toni’s loved ones back her decision, with daughter Josie saying: “Mum is of the time when celebrities would not admit to having cosmetic surgery. “Now with new technology and safer procedures, it is more accessible to people so why shouldn’t they benefit ”

story: NewsMum believes her dad traded places so toddler son with cancer could liveBernie Browns Korean war veteran dad was diagnosed with cancer on the same same day her son Finn finished his own treatmentShareCommentsByCaislin BoyleTim Wyatt:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsBernie and Andrew Brown with sons Toby, , Finn, eight, and six-year-old Sebastian "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grieving mum believes her dad traded places with her son when he was diagnosed with the disease - on the same day her toddler finished his own treatment. Bernie Brown is convinced her brave father Jim Brown somehow swapped places with little Finn, dying from the cruel condition as the youngster began to recover. Throughout two-year-old Finns battle with cancer Jim, , often said he wished he could trade places with the brave tot.But in a tragic twist of fate, Jims wish seemed to come true when he was taken to hospital with lung cancer in  just as Finn was winning his own battle.Jim, a veteran of the Korean War, passed away just  weeks later. Finn is now eight having battled the disease before his second birthday.Now, Bernie has written a moving poem to express her love for her dad, the Liverpool Echo reported.“He had sat on our sofa on diagnosis day and wept and said, it should have been me, I am an old man, Bernie recalled.   “It didn’t take long before I reflected on the meaning behind my dad’s diagnosis and his clear wish to trade places with Finn. Called Why Him Not Me , the poem has been entered into a competition in Liverpool as part of the th anniversary of the cancer charity Pause for Hope. “[The poem] is testament to my dad who, in the face of his terminal diagnosis, was courageous enough to know it was right he died to allow his grandson to live, Bernie said. “He took this responsibility in the same way as when a -year-old he went to Korea to serve in the forgotten war.” In another bittersweet moment, Bernie was heavily pregnant with her third son Sebastian when Jim was taken into hospital with lung cancer and gave birth on the same day Jims last battle ended and he died. She said: “I take great comfort from the belief that it was a trade and the events that followed including Sebastian’s birth on the day of the funeral only confirmed my spiritual sense that this was a le cycle moment,a precious gt of le from granddad to grandson, from father to daughter. “I am proud to be his daughter.” Why Him not Me  Bernies poem in full... title: one 20 adults uk dont
story: NewsOne in  adults in the UK dont believe the Holocaust happenedConcentration camp survivor Steven Frank has labelled the shocking findings, which were released on Holocaust Memorial Day, "terribly worrying"ShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  JAN NewsVictims of the Buchenwald concentration camp, near Weimar, Germany, liberated by the American troops of the th Division in  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne in  adults in the UK do not believe the Holocaust happened, a shocking new survey has found.The statistics, which have been published on Holocaust Memorial Day , have been labelled terribly worrying by concentration camp survivor Steven Frank.One in  of those surveyed believes it has been exaggerated, and almost two-thirds didnt know or grossly under-estimated the number of people who were killed. Mr Frank, , who was one of  children who survived the Theresienstadt camp in Czechoslovakia along with his two brothers, said he was surprised by the Holocaust Memorial Day Trusts findings. His father, who helped hide Jews as part of the Dutch Resistance, was arrested in Amsterdam and taken to Auschwitz in Nazi-occupied Poland, where he was gassed on January  .   He said: In my experience, people dont have a solid understanding of what happened during the Holocaust and thats one of the reasons I am so committed to sharing what happened to me. At one of my talks, I met someone who said the Holocaust didnt happen. The only way to fight this kind of denial and anti-Semitism is with the truth - I tell people what happened, what I saw and what I experienced. Education is so important. If we ignore the past, I fear history will repeat itself. The Holocaust Memorial Day Trust surveyed , adults in the UK for the new survey. Karen Pollock, chief executive of the Holocaust Educational Trust, said: We know that education is vital in the fight against ignorance and hate.   Whatever the statistics, one person questioning the truth of the Holocaust is one too many and so it is up to us to redouble our efforts to ensure future generations know that it did happen and become witnesses to one of the darkest episodes in our history. Today hundreds of people, including survivors, politicians and members of the public, will gather to mark Holocaust Memorial Day and remember its six million Jewish victims. More than , activities are expected to take place, while ceremonies will be held in London, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. A national commemorative ceremony will take place in Westminster to mark the day, which is also acknowledging the th anniversary of the genocide in Rwanda and  years since the end of the genocide in Cambodia. HMDT chief executive Olivia Marks-Woldman said: The Holocaust threatened the fabric of civilisation and has implications for us all. Such widespread ignorance and even denial is shocking.   Without a basic understanding of this recent history, we are in danger of failing to learn where a lack of respect for dference and hostility to others can ultimately lead. With a rise in reported hate crime in the UK and ongoing international conflicts with a risk of genocide, our world can feel fragile and vulnerable. We cannot be complacent. Communities Secretary James Brokenshire, who will be speaking at Sundays event, said: It remains essential now as ever to remember the Holocaust, to understand why it happened and to learn the stark lessons it gives. We must never forget where hatred and bigotry can lead. He added: This Government is clear that anti-Semitism has no place in our society and we all have a role to play in confronting hatred and extremism whenever and wherever it occurs.

title: operation ritz clever plan brought
story: NewsOperation Ritz: Clever plan which brought Charles and Camillas relationship out of shadowsMedia experts crafted a clever plan to introduce the world officially to Prince Charles and Camilla as a couple, and it worked a treatShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  JAN NewsThe couple were photographed thousands of times in just a few seconds "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email years ago today the worlds media gathered outside one of Londons most famous hotels for what would be a truly historic moment for the Royal Family. Operation Ritz was a perfectly planned moment which saw Prince Charles and Camilla appear together as a couple for the first time after keeping their relationship in the shadows for years. They finally made their relationship official when they stepped out of the Ritz Hotel together after celebrating the th birthday of Camillas sister Annabel Elliott on January , . The photo op was the brainchild of spin doctor Mark Bolland, who reportedly ed to the UK from LA just to oversee the operation. And it worked - and the photographs appeared on the front page of every British newspaper alongside surprisingly warm words.  Camilla arrived at the hotel at .pm with her children Tom and Laura, and the group were greeted by the hotel manager ready to start the party. Charles arrived two hours later, at about .pm, having spent the evening at a charity dinner at St Jamess Palace. He walked to the hotel through Green Park, carrying a birthday present for the host. As they left together photographers got the picture they had been waiting for for years - a snap of the couple together. Photographers took so many photos during the short appearance that the British Epilepsy Association urged broadcasters not to use the clips on TV because there were so many flashes. Mr Bolland was put in charge of dealing with the Camilla Factor since way before the death of Princess Diana.  He managed to discreetly position her under the Palace wing, and closed down major areas of risk as she got ready to step into the public spotlight, reports the Independent. Before the joint appearance there were several near misses, most of which were pulled at the last minute. The first date in the diary was a gala for the National Osteoporosis Society, in late . However Camilla cancelled it after the death of Princess Diana. They were then going to make a joint appearance at the wedding of Santa Palmer-Tomkinson - the daughter of Camillas best friend Patti - but decided it would upstage the bride and groom. So in the end they settled on Annabels private birthday, and she was reportedly delighted to help out. How the Mirror covered the story at the time CHARLES and Camilla felt an overwhelming sense of relief as they prepared to face the world together. Almost  years of secrecy was to be banished with their exit side by side from a party at Londons Ritz Hotel late last night. And hours before the dramatic moment, a top royal source said: They are very relieved its all ending. The Prince believes that the pressure on them was becoming increasingly silly.  They hope now they can be allowed to get on and lead ordinary lives. Yesterday an array of stepladders outside the five-star Ritz in Arlington Street off Piccadilly was evidence of the host of camera crews waiting to capture the couples coming-out - scheduled for .pm. Charles, , is said to be well aware of the fortune a single snapper could make from an exclusive picture of him with -year-old Camilla. So, rather than let anyone profit at his emotional expense, he was prepared for an open house appearance. The source said: The prince has been mystied by the scale of interest in a first picture. But he does not want someone to make millions out of him. Visibly irritated by press demands during public s, the prince apparently insisted that he would not touch Camilla for last nights historic photograph. During the planning, he is said to have joked I am not going to hold her hand or give her a kiss. His attitude will certainly hit a raw nerve with supporters of Mrs Parker Bowles. Despite public vilication after the death of Princess Diana, she has remained loyal to Charles. The prince had been working on plans for their first public appearance for weeks. The Ritz party to celebrate the th birthday of Camillas sister Mrs Annabel Elliot provided the perfect opportunity.  Unlike an official engagement, where such a photograph could be seen as interfering with his public duties and giving Camilla a royal , the event is strictly a family affair. Friends revealed yesterday that the delicately-planned operation was pnt in jeopardy when Camilla developed a bad cold. Although she was still feeling unwell, the mother-of-two insisted on keeping the appointment. After the party the prince and Camilla were to step out of the main entrance of the -room Ritz into Arlington Street. Camilla was arriving early for the lavish gathering in the hotels largest banqueting room, called the Marie Antoinette Suite after the queen consort of King Louis XVI. Executive chef Giles Thompson was preparing the feast for  guests, family and friends of the Elliot and Parker Bowles families. Charles, who has been staying at Balmoral since January , was not expected to turn up until after pm. He was committed to hosting a dinner at nearby St Jarness Palace earlier in the evening. Photographers got a trial run when Charles and Camilla lookalikes drew up at the Ritz in a black chauffeur-driven Daimler. As newsmen rushed forward, the pranksters dressed in evening wear walked up the six front-entrance steps and waited for the flash-guns.   A Ritz official asked them to move on and they hurried away by car after a stunt believed to have been organised by a TV company. Timing was a major factor in the princes plans for last night. Public hostility towards Camilla after the death of Diana on August ,  has eased and recent opinion polls show that most people have accepted the relationship. There is another reason why it is so important for them to accelerate the campaign to have Camilla accepted as his official companion. can afford to es and Camilla steal the limelight from bride and groom. And to achieve that, the prince and Mrs Parker Bowles will have to be seen many times together. In the  months since Diana died, the coming-out of Camilla - orced from ex-army officer Andrew Parker Bowles in  - has been a gradual and often painful process. The first poll taken after Charles own orce was finalised in September  showed more than  per cent actively disliked Camilla. Worse was to come.   Shortly after Dianas death, Charles was dismissed as unlikely ever to be crowned. And  per cent of the public believed thathe married Camilla, he should give up the throne. They took the plunge together in July  with dinner at a private members club in London. They arrived separately, but left together at .pm without being spotted. Three months later, they were pictured - albeit apart - at the society wedding of Santa Palmer Tomkinson and writer Simon Sebag Montefiore in St Johns Wood. During the summer, Camilla had met Prince Harry with his father and last November she hosted a th birthday party for Charles at Highgrove, Gloucs. title: pregnant woman loses baby doctors
story: NewsPregnant woman loses baby when doctors at scandal-hit hospital misdiagnose herThe woman was admitted to the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow with severe abdominal painShareCommentsBySarah WardCaroline Wilson:,  JAN NewsQueen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A pregnant woman lost her baby after doctors at a scandal-hit hospital misdiagnosed her appendicitis as a stomach bug. The woman, who has not been named and instead referred to as Mrs C, was taken to the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow for treatment.The super-hospital, which is one of the largest in Europe, is already under scrutiny following a recent scandal. Two patients, including a -year-old boy, died due to an infection linked to pigeon droppings. NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde has admitted there were clear failings in the expectant mothers care, after a damning report was published. The woman was admitted to hospital with severe abdominal pain and suspected appendicitis. An ultrasound was carried out and she was treated for gastroenteritis, commonly referred to as stomach flu.  However, her condition deteriorated and she developed sepsis - and doctors discovered that her unborn baby had died.An inquiry found there was a catalogue of failures in the womans care including no review by an experienced obstetrician and a lack of physical examination by experienced doctors.Checks on her vital signs including blood pressure , respiratory and heart rate were not done appropriately and there was a failure to interpret the signs of sepsis. The reason for her deteriorating condition was discovered when she was opened up in the operating theatre and her appendix was removed. However she later developed sepsis and organ failure. The patient recovered after treatment but was readmitted twice more with infections in her abdominal muscles. The Scottish Public Services Ombudsmanupheld a complaint that there was an unreasonable failure to diagnose appendicitis and sepsis.   Doctors were said to have failed to adequately consider an alternative diagnosis to gastroenteritis and consideration should have been given to carrying out a CT scan or laparoscopy. The board was also criticised for delays in launching an investigation into the incident. A spokesman for the SPSO said: There was an unreasonable failure to diagnose Mrs C with both appendicitis and sepsis and, therefore, upheld Mrs Cs complaints.  A number of failings had been identied by the board, but we made some additional recommendations for learning and improvement. The hospital has been told to apologise to the patient and review the care of deteriorating patients, particularly those exhibiting signs of sepsis, with patients escalated to a senior doctor. A spokesman for NHSGCC said: We recognise there were clear failings in the patients care and will write to the patient to apologise. The Ombudsmans recommendations are being discussed by a multi-disciplinary team to identy how these can be quickly implemented and ensure that lessons learned in this case are shared with appropriate staff.

Meg later said the incident was absolutely horric and she didnt really sleep last night saying her body was aching. It is not known what prompted the pair to hurl timber at each other between the terraced houses, but a video of the battle suggests these two might have forgotten the old adage love thy neighbour.The Twitter user who posted the footage online tweeted that the row broke out early one morning, although it remains a mystery where, when and, indeed, why it ever began. title: american state first world allow
story: NewsAmerican state to be first in world to allow loved ones to become human compostWashington state residents "are excited about the prospect of becoming a tree”ShareCommentsByLaura Forsyth:,  JAN NewsIf a new bill is passed in Washington, loved ones can be turned into human compost"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email An American state could be set to be the first in the world to allow loved ones to become human compost . If a new bill is passed, this would make residents in Washington State, able to dispose of human remains by reducing them to soil through what has been called recomposition.So far there has been no opposition to the proposal and Washington residents are very excited about the prospect of becoming a tree or having a dferent alternative.” Recomposition involves putting bodies in a vessel and turning it into a nutrient-dense soil that can then be ed to families.   The aim is said to be a cheaper way of dealing with human remains and is better for the environment than burial. Burials can often spread chemicals into the ground, while cremation releases earth-warming carbon dioxide. Democrat State Senator Jamie Pedersen is sponsoring the bill in Washington’s Legislature to expand the options for disposing of human remains. He said: “People from all over the state who wrote to me are very excited about the prospect of becoming a tree or having a dferent alternative for themselves.”  The recomposition bill would also make Washington the th state to allow alkaline hydrolysis. This is the dissolving of bodies in a pressurised vessel with water and lye until just liquid and bone remains. Sen. Pedersen plans to introduce the bill next month when the new legislative session begins.

story: NewsBoy, , found after he went missing in woods for days says he hung out with a bearHundreds of people looked for Casey Hathaway after he disappeared for two days in North Carolina, USAShareCommentsByLaura Forsyth:,  JAN NewsApart from cuts and bruises the youngster seemed otherwise unharmed "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A young boy found after he went missing for two days in the woods said that he “hung out with a bear .”Casey Hathaway, had been playing outside his great-grandmother’s house with two other children on Tuesday. The three-year-old then apparently wandered off into the woods in North Carolina, USA, as reported by a local news channel WITN.Hundreds of people, drones, helicopters and search dogs looked for Casey but were unable to find him , according to the news channel.The area began to experience freezing temperatures and heavy rain over the following days, with many beginning to fear the worst for the boy.   Local woman Lisa Fraker had ed home on Thursday evening after getting involved in the search party. As she went to take her dogs out for a walk she heard what she believed to be a child crying near her home. Ms Fraker took her dogs back inside before contacting an emergency responder to listen to the noises. She told WITN: “Next thing I know, [the emergency responder] was coming back and telling me that yes, he heard something too. He said: “You could tell he was very cold so we immediately started warming him up once we got him to the vehicle. “The more we warmed him up, it seemed the better he got.”   An ambulance rushed the boy to a local hospital but apart from cuts and bruises, Casey seemed to be unharmed, according to WITN.His aunt Breanna Hathaway posted on Facebook that her nephew is well since he was found.She said: “Casey is healthy, smiling and talking. title: flush ah ah dundees toilets get international recognition as cultural gems
story: Dundee is flush with many cultural gems – museums, art galleries, performing art centres and scores of sculptures.What it hasn’t been renowned for is its toilets – until now.A pair of public toilets feature as two of Dundee’s  “Cultural Gems” on a new map published by the European Commission’s Joint Research Centre .The Castle Green and the Windmill public toilets are both featured on the map.They are each a stone’s throw from Broughty Castle, which could go some way to explaining how the public facilities have made the cut.The European Commission has just published its online cultural gems map, featuring places of interest on  cities from across the European continent.It puts Dundee on an equal standing with Glasgow, Edinburgh and London, as well as sprawling cultural kings such as Paris, Berlin, Rome and Vienna.The website can be accessed on desktop computers and mobile phones and has been designed with tourists in mind.European commissioner for culture, Tibor Navracsics, said: “Cultural Gems brings Europe’s hidden cultural treasures to your smartphone.“This app builds on the success of the Cultural and Creative City Monitor which helps city authorities and the cultural sector better understand the role and impact of culture and creativity.”As the project is still in its infancy, initial information for the online guide has been drawn from OpenStreetMap, an online  akin to a Wikipedia for maps that anyone can edit.Both Castle Green and Windmill are listed as public toilets on Open Street Map, which could explain how they came to be part of the guide.But with other public conveniences also listed on the app but not the cultural guide, quite how the pair of Ferry facilities came to be considered “cultural gems” remains a mystery.Council leader John Alexander saw the funny side of the listing.He said: “It was likely that some things in the city were going to be missed – but I didn’t think it would pick up things like that.”However, the project is equally open to new contributions – meaning bodies such as Dundee City Council can add their own highlights – and perhaps remove those less deserving.The public can also make contributions by creating an online account at culturalgems.jrc.ec.europa.eu, and can climb to the top of a local leader board by adding extra cultural points of interest to the Dundee guide.Mr Alexander, a councillor for the Strathmartine ward, added: “In my own ward we have the beautul, cross-generational mural behind the Kirkton Asda. That’s cultural, it’s not on the map, and it should be.“There are loads of dferent things that could be on the map and I hope it gets people thinking about their own ideas of what should be there.“It’s a real strength that our city is considered an equal alongside cities like Bilbao, Helsinki and Barcelona.“We can’t create jobs and investment unless we extend outwith Scotland – culture is a really good way of doing that.“The map is another string to our bow.”Aside from the commode additions in Broughty Ferry, the City of Discovery’s scores of cultural highlights are all present and correct.Key buildings such as the DCA, The McManus, Dundee Rep and the VA all make the cut in the city centre – as do dozens of city churches, statues and sculptures.Assurances have been given Dundee will still feature on the map post-Brexit. vw, px"  Dundee isn’t alone in having public loos accidentally highlighted as “cultural gems”.Glasgow has one, in the northern suburb of Stepps, while UK capital London boasts of no fewer than  “culturally signicant” toilets on the Cultural Gems map.Paris has four, while Barcelona has one. In Scandanavia, Danish capital Copenhagen has listings for five.However, Portguese capital Lisbon takes the cultural loo crown with  listed public facilities on the guide.The reasons for toilets being picked up alongside sculptures, art galleries and theatres, isn’t all that clear.Upon the project website’s launch last year, European Commission bosses said the data was based on locations listed in OpenStreetMap as “points of interest”.As a result, it appears any item listed as a “point of interest” made it into the guide without being checked.The European Commission said: “The map is crowd-sourced.“Therefore citizens, local administrators and not-for-profit-organisations are key to uploading content about their cities.“Nevertheless, the programme comes with maps providing an initial set of points of interest for European cities in the app from OpenStreetMap.”Toilets aside, the guide is a highly detailed way of finding out about a city’s achievements and its contributions to art.The comprehensive database already offers up thousands of cinemas, art galleries, sites of historical signicance and music venues.Alongside the big hitters, it lists churches and community halls – where real local culture can be found every day.

title: landmark dundee shop set to be moved for 130 home development
story: A landmark city shop will be moved as part of proposals for a new housing estate.The demolition of The Kiosk in its current form is due to be carried out once the houses of Ellengowan estate are taken down.Planning permission is being sought to demolish the empty homes, which were built as temporary accommodation between the wars.The new development would see  homes – a mix of houses and flats – built in their place.The small convenience store on the corner of Arbroath Road and Dalkeith Road has been a community staple for almost  years.While work is taking place the shop will be temporarily moved to a blue portable building down the street. When it is finished the shop will relocate to its new home.Kiosk owner Kay Carnegie said: “I don’t know what the future will hold.“We have lost a lot of customers with the houses being empty, we have lost a lot of our regulars. A lot of people say it is a landmark. Lots of people remember having a paper round here.“The shop is quite old and cold, I think it has probably had its day. It is time for a change. I will miss it.”Hillcrest director of developments David Zwirlein said: “Redevelopment plans for Ellengowan Drive are progressing well. We have successfully relocated the tenants, and a demolition contractor is in the process of being appointed. Demolition should begin early this year following approval of the plans.“Once the demolition has been carried out the construction phase will begin, representing an exciting milestone.“The previous houses were built as a temporary measure in , yet have been occupied for more than  years.“The redevelopment project will bring brand new high-quality homes with the latest energy efficiency innovations to residents, along with landscaped community spaces and access roads.”

title: rock choir making big noises in perth rolls in to dundee
story: An inclusive choir which has gone from strength to strength in Perth is preparing to set up in Dundee.The Rock Choir, whose repertoire includes a ied mix of modern and classic rock and pop numbers, will be seeking new members when it sets up its all-abilities singing group later this year.The choir group already has successful branches in Perth and Glenrothes which are set to grace the stage at Disneyland Paris in the near-future.Rachel Leitch, who takes the Perth, Glenrothes and Stirling choirs, said they were looking forward to welcoming a wide range of singers.She said: “We have a real mix of folk in our choirs and we have disabled as well as able bodied people.“The only thing we ask is that you are keen to sing.“There are good numbers in the choirs in Perth, Glenrothes and Stirling, some folk who have choir experience and some who have never sung before but want to do so.“As well as the serious side, we have great fun and being in the choir is a fine way of making new friends.“We have all ages in our choirs and from all backgrounds.“In Perth, our youngest is  and our oldest is .“Folk can come and seethey like it and,so, fine.“The door is open to everybody.”The choirs perform locally and at national events and  members are going to sing at Disneyland Paris at the end of June.Cindy Godfrey-McKay is one of the Perth choir members who has found the Rock Choir to be a real home from home.Cindy, a Dundee woman now living in the Fair City, has only % sight and suffers from arthritis.She said: “Being a choir member has helped me greatly.“I was in a wheelchair and knowing the choir had an event at Perth Concert Hall I was determined I wasn’t going to sing at it in my wheelchair.“I motivated myself to stand while singing and I managed it.“There are other disabled folk in the Perth choir and I would encourage other disabled people to get involved.“To have the choir starting in Dundee is absolutely brilliant.“Rachel is really good with everyone.“She helps us all so much and she is very supportive.“Everybody is very friendly as well. It’s a right good crowd and we all have a great time in practise and in concert.”

title: scott-sinclair-criticism-has-been-well-off-the-mark-says-celtics-callum-mcgregor
story: Callum McGregor has insisted that any criticism of Scott Sinclair is unwarranted. The -year-old netted his eighth goal in seven games in the - win over Hamilton Accies at the weekend to take his tally for the season to  - just one behind Celtics top scorer Odsonne Edouard. And McGregor has insisted that he has never been under any illusion as to just what Sinclair brings to the team. "He is on an excellent run," said the midfielder. "The thing with Scotty is that I keep hearing people saying that he is not playing well and yet he is scoring goals week in, week out for us. "I think he set his standard so high in that first season when he was almost unplayable at times. "There isnt a player in the world who doesnt take a dip at some point but he has always chipped in with goals and assists - I think last season he scored  goals for us. Its not bad, is it  "The last few games we are seeing him going past people, he is calling for the ball all the time and he is winning penalties and scoring goals so I am delighted for him. "As players we always know what he brings and how important he is to the team. But I am delighted for him because he definitely looks as though he is bang on form again and that is good news for us." Meanwhile, McGregor has insisted that he wont be asking for a rest after featuring in every one of Celtics games this season. Between club and country McGregor has played  matches but he is in no mood to down tools for a breather. "I feel good," he said. "I think you always want to play, especially when the team is winning and successful and you want to be a part of that. "It hasnt crossed my mind that I would go and say that I needed to take a rest. Physically I feel good. I dont have any injury problems and I love being out there. "Its a privilege to player here and Id be delighted to go and play every game now this seasonI could." Celtic host St Johnstone on Wednesday evening, the start of a run of games against the Perthshire side between the Scottish Cup, the league and a rearranged fixture. Taking three points would enable Celtic to stretch further ahead at the top of the table with McGregor keen to keep the winning home run going. "We always just take it every game at a time," he said. "It can be a bit odd when you are playing the same team so often in a short space of time. "But it happened last season against Motherwell and the manager shook things up a bit for every game. I think in the third game against them we won - so I think we will always look to try and keep it fresh. "In terms of Wednesday night it is just a chance now to keep this wee run of form going. Hopefully we can take all three points but we know that it will be a tough night for us. "St Johnstone will make it hard for us but its up to us to go and find a way past them."

title: Call for Inverness to get a share of cash for shop conversions
story: CONCERNS have been raised that Inverness could be denied a share of funding to help the hardest-pressed local high streets turn empty shops into housing.Mike Smith, manager of the cityrsquos Business Improvement Districtfears a move by the Federation of Small Businessesto persuade the Scottish Government to split a pound million fund between the poorest-performing high streets only could see a relatively buoyant Inverness miss out.ldquoI donrsquot think thatrsquos fair, he said.ldquoAll high streets are under certain pressures. Retail is a commercial venture and we do not think that public funds should be given tosupport one retail sector against another.ldquoI think this pound million should be fairly split on a population basis and should be used in an equal way to improve the infrastructure.Mr Smith stressed that some local authorities will already be investing in this way and their successes ldquoshould not be held against them.He said the redevelopment of Academy Streetrsquos former Farmfoods supermarket was ldquoa good example of shops being turned into homes in the city with the local authorityrsquos support.The development there will include  one-bedroom and  two-bedroom flats as well as four retail and office units on the ground floor.A spokesman for FSB nationally said: ldquoIt is far too early to tell which high streets will benefit from this fund.ldquoWersquore making the case for each local authority to use this money in the places that it could make the most dference.FSB Highlands and Islands development manager David Richardson said: ldquoRather than spreading the money too thinly for it to have any impact, the FSB wants it to be focused on ersying our hardest-pressed high streets and is calling for local authorities to establish new co-investment funds to improve and convert existing properties. We must make more of what wersquove already got. Allied to this is the need for joined-up thinking amongst public bodies. Given that thriving high streets and village centres are inextricably linked to the health and wellbeing of their communities, it is important that all interested parties work in partnership.Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister said she would be calling on colleagues to get round the table for some strategic planning to make sure the city gets a share of the funding.She believes the rate of shop closures in the Highland capital and the long waiting list for homes puts the city at the front of the queue.She said: ldquoIrsquom going to have a chat with the city centre manager, David Hass, and get people around the table to see how we can get our hands on that money.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Drive on to extend free parking in Inverness city centre
story: CITY businesses are pushing for an extension to free parking in the centre of Inverness as a year-long trial they have hailed as a success comes to an end.Backed by the Inverness Courier, Inverness Business Improvement Districtpersuaded Highland Council to introduce a system of free  minutes of on-street parking last year across a broad swathe of the city centre.Parking meters were converted to provide free tickets for  on-street spaces, after research suggested similar schemes have had a positive impact on footfall in other urban centres such as Perth.The trial period is now coming to an end and business figures, who argue it has been a hit, are hoping it will be extended ndash both in terms of the amount of time shoppers will be able to enjoy free parking for and the number of sites they can us.Local butcher Duncan Fraser who has premises in Queensgate said: ldquoThe businesses I have spoken to would like to see it extended to half an hour.ldquoFteen minutes is fine, but a bit tightyou have to go to a couple of shops or get caught up in the post office.ldquoWe certainly would not like to see this withdrawn.And David Miele, who runs the hugely successful Mielersquos Gelateria in Church Street, is also hoping councillors will look at making better use of the parking space available.ldquoThere are too many loading bays which lie empty for most of the day, he said.ldquoWhen wardens pass our premises customers basically get up and go out because they fear getting a ticket.ldquoI welcome the free parking and would like to see it increased.They are being backed in their calls by Inverness Central councillor and depute provost Bet McAllisterldquoIt has clearly been welcomed by the traders and enables people to get in to the town centre and attend to business, but you canrsquot do a lot in  minutes, she said.ldquoI would rather see it extended to half an hour so people can pop into a couple of shops, go to the library or even stop for a coffee.And she added: ldquoMany older people would benefit greatly from a longer stay.ldquoWe have to look at the bigger picture. The Victorian Market is generally used by older people and it needs more customers. Longer-stay free parking would help.BID manager Mike Smith said it believes the free parking has been beneficial.ldquoInverness BID subscribes to the view that parking is all part of the city centre marketing offer to the public, he said.ldquoWe appreciate the financial pressures Highland Council is under, but we should not lose sight of that mantra.Shane Manning, principal officer for traffic and planning at Highland Council, confirmed councillors are set to evaluate the schemersquos impact when the Inverness city area committee meets on February . They will decide at that point whether to continue with it.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Funding could lead to new life for Inverness park
story: A BOLD vision to transform a historic Inverness park into a vibrant green space and breathe new le into its dilapidated buildings could take a step forward later this month.Campaigners are exploring the possibility of transferring ownership of the Northern Meeting Park in Ardross Street to a community-run group in a bid to enable greater access to the venue.The Northern Meeting Park Group is now waiting to hear whether a funding application has been successful for a feasibility study to prepare a five-year business plan plus architectural reports and surveys.If all goes according to plan, the study could begin before the end of January while the long-awaited project could be achieved by the end of next year.The group is also looking for two trustees from the local community ndash taking in the neighbourhoods of Park, Balleary and Dalneigh and Columba ndash to join its -strong board.Chairman Jon Ford expects this year to be a busy one in trying to push forward the proposals for the -year-old park whose gates are usually kept locked.The group has applied for a grant from the Scottish Land Fund with advice from Highlands and Islands Enterprise and hopes to get match funding from the Architectural Heritage Fund.In total, the initial studies are expected to cost pound,.ldquoWe know there are a lot of other people out there also looking for funding but we are very optimistic, he said.ldquoThat would be the first stage. The next stage would be to apply for funding to acquire the Northern Meeting Park and have it transferred into community ownership.Highland Council would also have to agree to transfer ownership of the park.Mr Ford acknowledged there had been some resistance from a few councillors including those who had mistakenly thought the idea was to turn the park into a private business venture.ldquoNone of us likes change, he said. ldquoI can understand it on one level but not on another when you are talking about a publicly-owned asset which is kept locked up and not used especially as it is four acres of grass in the city centre which could be used for recreation.ldquoI cannot understand why people are resistant to that notion. In our view this is a way for Highland Council to think outside the box.Hundreds of people accessed the park during a two-week trial last summer when the gates were opened each day between am and pm.Mr Ford hopes a similar trial will be carried out around Easter.Anyone interested in becoming a trustee can contact the group via www.northernmeetingpark, or call  .Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Hope that Inverness special needs project can be saved
story: Highland Councilrsquos refusal to fund the Special Needs Action Projectin Inverness has triggered outrage across party lines with councillors and members of parliament queuing up to slam the local authority.Conservative councillor Andrew Jarvie, said: ldquoNot only is this a devastating blow for dozens upon dozens of vulnerable children and young people, it symbolises everything that is wrong with this council administration.Mr Jarvie complained the decision to refuse funding was taken in private, saying: ldquoThis secrecy and behind closed door decisions wreaked havoc on rural communities last year but I find it absolutely disgusting to inflict the same on the most vulnerable people in Highland.ldquoFor SNAP to run such a comprehensive and valuable year round service for pound, a year tells me that they are already managing their funds stringently and that any cut is a gross insult to both the organisation and its users.MP Drew Hendry met with SNAP management last week and he said: ldquoAnybody who knows about the great work SNAP do would also be very concerned by the uncertainty around their future and just how dficult it would be to replace the work that they do.ldquoA better way forward must be to secure their immediate future and to work with them to find sustainable funding for coming years.ldquoThis approach has worked successfully before and I have pledged to do what I can to support SNAP and the council to find a better outcome.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Inverness charity issues go orange plea for fundraising effort
story: INVERNESS charity Leorsquos Pride is encouraging people to lsquoGo orange for a dayrsquo as ambassadors in this yearrsquos Muscular Dystrophy UKevent on February .The national campaign has been running for three years and has so far made more than pound, by encouraging schools, workplaces and iniduals to wear orange for a day and make a donation to MDUK.Additionally those taking part can choose to wear sunglasses or even set up a mock-tail bar, in order to raise funds.Leorsquos Pride is a local organisation which was set up for Leo Flett, who is three-years-old and suffers from Muscular Dystrophy . Leorsquos mum Louise said: ldquoThe support we have had since starting almost a year ago is absolutely incredible and we continue to be touched by peoplersquos kindness and generosity.Mrs Flett said: ldquoWe are totally blown away by this yearrsquos response. We have been very lucky and honoured to have been asked to be ambassadors for the day this year by MDUK which means a lot to us considering wersquore still so new.The charity is raising money to continue their work finding new treatments and campaigning for better care and support for people with muscle-wasting conditions to ensure them the best possible quality of le.Muscular Dystrophy UK regional development manager, Dean Widd said: ldquoA huge thank you to everyone in Inverness looking to take part in the national Go Orange for a Day on February . We are delighted that over a dozen schools, clubs, academies and businesses have registered to take part in support of our Scottish family fund Leorsquos Pride.Mr Widd said: ldquoIt is thanks to the incredible efforts like this that we are able to continue to fund pioneering research into potential treatments for muscular dystrophy as well as supporting families. With more than , people in the UK living with muscular dystrophy and other muscle-wasting conditions, it is important to do whatever we can to make a dference.Leorsquos Pride is also organising an event in April called Pride  after last yearrsquos event which made over pound,.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Leading Inverness football figure to live on with launch of fundraising campaign
story: THE memory of a leading Inverness football figure will live on with the launch of a fundraising campaign to help renal patients and raise awareness of kidney failure.Sandyrsquos Army will be launched in memory of Sandy Corcoran, the founder of Inverness City Ladies, on what would have been his th birthday.Mr Corcoran, who died three days before Christmas, had lived with type one diabetes for many years and then developed kidney failure resulting in him undergoing long dialysis sessions in Raigmore Hospitalrsquos renal unit.His family, including we, Valerie, son Steven and daughter Ashley Mackinnon, plus five grandchildren, are now raising funds for the unit at a dinner dance featuring live music and comedians at the cityrsquos Kingsmillrsquos Hotel on April .At the stroke of midnight, Sandyrsquos Army will be launched heralding more fundraising events in the coming year.Mrs Mackinnon said just  tickets remain for the event after  were snapped up in three days.ldquoWe want the night to be a massive celebration and we want to remember what an unbelievable person he was, she said. ldquoIt is going to be a sensational tribute to him as a person helping others and he would have wanted it no other way. It will be a hard day but I feel that being with those who loved him it will make it easier.Although Mr Corcoran was diagnosed with diabetes  years ago, he managed his condition but then developed kidney failure five years ago.With the support of his family, he started home dialysis but when it became too dficult he had to swap to six-hour sessions three days a week in the renal unit.ldquoThe unit became like a family to us, Mrs Mackinnon recalled. ldquoThey were just incredible to my dad. I noticed he was never on his own. They work tirelessly  hours a day, seven days a week.He was due to have a kidney and pancreas transplant but then developed bone marrow failure resulting in him having blood transfusions which meant he could not have a transplant.Sadly, Mr Corcoran, who was also the manager of Inverness Precast, died on December . Over  people attended his funeral.ldquoHe faced everything with the most unbelievable courage. I never once heard dad complain, Mrs Mackinnon said.She added that the family want to give something back to the renal unit and, as well as the dinner, planned fundraisers include an ascent of Ben Nevis.ldquoThis is a way of helping others through his memory.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Parents criticise new school bus service across Inverness
story: SCHOOL bus services have been in chaos since a council contract changed hands at the start of the month it has been claimed.Parents say a move to double up dedicated school runs with services for the general public since transport giant Stagecoach took over the Highland Council schools contract from DE Coaches on January  has seen pupils regularly forced to endure late-running and dangerously overcrowded buses.Police have also confirmed they are investigating allegations that pupils were threatened with a weapon on board a bus between Kirkhill and Charleston Academy on January .Mum Carol Paterson, whose daughter travels from Croy to Culloden Academy, said the problems are known about across Inverness.ldquoThe children at Croy are waiting sometimes up to  minutes in freezing conditions because the buses are now regularly late, she said.ldquoAnd when they board the bus there are not enough seats.Jools Lawson, whose daughter attends Charleston Academy, said: ldquoKids are regularly having to stand on a jam-packed bus or being put off altogether and told to wait for another one.ldquoThe service is disgusting and Stagecoach brush our complaints under the carpet.Posts from a private Facebook group set up for parents of pupils using school buses and shown to the Inverness Courier make clear the extent of unhappiness since the changeover.Other alleged incidents include children being put off a bus beside a busy main road without a pavement and two incidents involving Inverness Royal Academy pupils ndash one where a bus did not turn up at home time and another where the bus was too small to accommodate them.Highland Council has issued two separate statements in response to concerns raised ndash one with regard to a public service operating en route to Inverness Gaelic Primary stating it is unlikely to involve ldquoroutes which the public are likely to want to use and another on the Charleston Academy-Kirkhill route stating ldquomeasures have been put in place to make improvements.Despite this an online petition has been launched calling for the reinstatement of dedicated school services.Signed by almost  people so far it states: ldquoWhen putting our children on a school bus it used to be the case that it was only school children on these buses, therefore anyone travelling was accounted for and any incidents easily dealt with and tracked.ldquoNow we have opened the floodgates to allowing our children to be exposed to anything on these buses.Councillor for Culloden and Ardersier, Glynis Campbell-Sinclair, said Highland Council needs to launch its own investigation into whether there is a serious problem with how buses taking pupils to and from schools operate.ldquoThey cannot jam pack children onto buses like pilchards and hope there is not going to be an accident - especially in this weather, she said.ldquoEvery parent that sends their child to school by bus is depending on the council to ensure that happens safely.ldquoIt is the councilrsquos responsibility as corporate parent to ensure these children get to school safely.A spokeswoman for Stagecoach North Scotland said: ldquoSince we started operating the additional school contracts on January  there have been some issues with capacity we have identied and are working to resolve.ldquoWe are working closely with Highland Council to resolve these problems by issuing school children with passes allocating them to specic buses to prevent the overloading problems we have seen.She added that in terms of the issues raised by Mrs Paterson an title: Work starts on new outlets at Eastgate Shopping Centre
story: WORK has begun at the Eastgate Shopping Centre in Inverness to develop four food outlets.The units, suitable for restaurant or bar operators, are being created by the reconfiguration of two existing shops fronting Falcon Square.Burger King UK is the first operator to sign up while talks are ongoing with operators for the other units.In addition, a new kiosk will be created fronting the Falcon Square mall entrance. Possible uses include an outlet for a food takeaway.The development comes as the cityrsquos nearby rail station is set to undergo a pound million upgrade while a public consultation is currently ongoing into a bold vision to transform Academy Street to make it more pedestrian-friendly.Alasdair Murdoch, chief executive of Burger King UK, said: ldquoWe are excited to expand the Burger King brand in Inverness and look forward to welcoming guests to experience the great-tasting, high-quality food that has delighted Burger King customers for  years.Local building and construction company Compass expects to hand over the units in late May to be fitted out and managing director Thom Macleod is delighted it has been appointed principal contractor for the redevelopment of the former Monsoon and Mamas and Papas unit.ldquoHaving been involved extensively in the planning of the project, it is pleasing to now be making preparations for the works to get formally under way on site, he said.Previous proposals involved an extension into Falcon Square or rooftop bar but were altered to attract a wider range of operators.Centre manager Jackie Cuddy said it will be business usual while work proceeds.ldquoWe are delighted to see the works progressing after several enforced delays over the yearsshe said. ldquoThe market may have changed since we first started out on this journey but we are still optimistic that we can provide a great addition to the night time economy of Inverness with this development.Monday  Jan  : AM

story: A photography club has been congratulated after it won thousands of pounds of funding.Craigewan Photographic Club, near Peterhead, will receive £, from the National Lottery Awards for All Scotland programme.The group intends to spend the money on a projector, a new laptop, four new cameras and additional equipment to help attract new, younger members to join the club.Banff and Buchan MP David Duguid said he was delighted.He added: “It was fantastic to hear that Craigewan Photographic Club has received £, in funding.“This sum will make a considerable dference to the group and will allow for a lot more equipment to be purchased.“Hopefully it will also encourage more people to get involved with the club.“The National Lottery Awards for All programme has been the source of funding for many good organisations.”

title: charlie house urges public to take on aberdeen 10k to raise cash for charity
story: Members of the public are being urged to sign up to take on a popular Aberdeen running challenge.Charlie House, which supports children and babies with complex disabilities and or le-limiting conditions, is offering spaces in the BHGE K Running Festival for keen runners, who will help to raise money for the charity’s Big Build Appeal.The event has been going for a number of years, with the main K event taking place alongside a fun run.It is the second time the charity has taken part.A total of  spaces are available for people to sign up to, which will see them support Charlie House.Those representing the charity are asked to raise a minimum of £.In November, Charlie House launched its Big Build Appeal, an £ million fundraising campaign to build a specialist support centre, which would be the first of its kind in the north-east, based in four acres of ground at Woodend Hospital.Rhona Miller, team fundraising manager at Charlie House, said: “This is our second year being involved with the BHGE K Running Festival.“We were delighted with the response gained from last year and hope this increases with further support from our fundraisers in May.”Money raised will go towards the campaign, which aims to build an eight-bedroom facility with associated family accommodation.As well as providing respite care for children and their families, it will also have a range of dferent facilities such as a sensory room, library, spa pool, craft room, teen den, soft play area, therapy room, star room for end-of-le care and bereavement, outdoor play area and sensory gardens, as well as adaptable meeting and office space for employees and medical staff.The BHGE K is to take place on May , and is organised by Sport Aberdeen, in partnership with BHGE and Aberdeen City Council. The route is based around Aberdeen’s beach and harbour area.It then moves along the Beach Esplanade, up King Street, through Seaton, along Golf Road and Urquhart Road before rejoining the route at the finish line. The K will start at .am, and the K at am.The K will begin at the Beach Leisure Centre and will loop past Pittodrie, and is open for children in P up to S.Wheelchair users are also encouraged to take part, with an adjusted start time of .am for the K, and .am for the K.Anyone interested in signing up to fundraise for Charlie House should contact fundraise@charliehouse.org.ukCharlie House was set up in , and as well as raising funds for the Big Build Appeal it also runs activity clubs, siblings clubs, annual adventure trips and it has its own community nurse, all which it fundraises for throughout the year.Charlie House launches £ million appeal to build specialist care centre for north-east children" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local charlie-house-launches--million-appeal-to-build-specialist-care-centre-for-north-east-children embed # secretDqXQqVJZls" data-secret"DqXQqVJZls" width"" "" title"#Charlie House launches £ million appeal to build specialist care centre for north-east children# # Evening Express" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"

title: plans lodged for 300 new homes near aberdeens haudagain roundabout
story: Plans have been formally lodged to build almost  homes and retail space beside a notorious roundabout.Housebuilder Dandara has applied to Aberdeen City Council to transform the so-called “Middlefield Triangle” into  residential units and to develop more than ,sq ft of land into retail, food and drink or leisure space.The triangle will be created through building a connecting road between North Anderson Drive and Auchmill Road.The project aims to reduce pressure on the Haudagain roundabout – once dubbed the worst in Europe.Diggers and cranes moved in last year and began tearing down a former housing estate on the site which the council said was of “poor quality” – rehoming  tenants who lived there.The proposal of application notice has been formally submitted to build a mixed-use development, but detailed regeneration plans are still to come forward.Residents have previously told the council they want to see shops and green space on the land.It was revealed last year that several retailers, who have not been named by the council, have expressed an interest in opening up on the land.However, SNP members of the opposition previously voiced concern that, under the present plans, there would not be enough green space and it would end up resembling “a pond with a bit of land around it”.Two public drop-in exhibition events are being offered for residents to look at and comment on the plans for the site.These have been scheduled for March  and  at the Henry Rae Community Centre on Manor Avenue.The exhibitions will run between pm and pm, with the first hour reserved for community councils and elected representatives to attend.Staff from Dandara and the design team will be in attendance to discuss the proposals and answer questions about them.The overall £. million Haudagain roundabout improvement scheme will see a new road created to connect North Anderson Drive and Auchmill Road.Farrans Construction has been appointed to carry out the work, which is set to get under way this year.The route is expected to be completed in March .Advance work at Haudagain began during the summer, which involved ground investigations, advance utility work and the demolition of  properties.Undertaking the demolition work ahead of the main construction project will provide Farrans Construction with a clear site to begin the task of constructing the new carriageway as soon as possible.Once complete, the m of new dual carriageway will remove traffic from a major bottleneck.

title: bain gains comeback ticket for place in top flight
story: Aberdeen darts player Jamie Bain is “more relieved than anything” to regain his Professional Darts Corporationtour card.Bain, , had lost his card after a dficult year, but came through a four-day, -player qualying school in Wigan to get it back.The Seaton player, who – after a run to the quarter-finals on the second day – almost had to pull out of the event due to a mysterious foot injury, can now look forward to another two years on the pro circuit as one of  Q school competitors to secure their PDC futures.Bain, who first earned his card in , said: “I’m more relieved than anything.“I didn’t have a great year last year. There were a lot of things – I had a wedding to pay for, it was stressful.“I had too many things on my mind.“I’ve got a clear path in front of me now for the next two years, so hopefully it goes a lot better.”Bain described his Q school experience as “torture”, explaining: “Before it started we were sitting looking at the numbers and it was close to .“But it wasn’t the numbers, it was the sheer quality of the players who were there.“You had world champions, finalists, major winners – it was just nuts.“You just take one game at a time. It’s all you can do, really.“It’s a new comp every day and every win you’ve got, you’ve got a point.”Bain won five matches on the Friday, but thinks he deserved more from the first day.He said: “It was weird. I played my best darts on the first day, yet somehow did better on the second day.“On the first day my scoring was amazing, with mid- averages really steady, but my doubles were atrocious.“Second day my scoring was ok, but my doubles were amazing.”Disaster then struck, with the former carpet-fitter saying: “I almost pulled out on the Saturday.“I woke up in the morning and couldn’t put weight on my right foot. It was a bit of panic.“I don’t have a clue what I did to it.“When I woke up in the morning, I walked along to the venue and just started to feel a pain.“It was bruised and swollen.“After that, I just had to grind through the last two days.”Bain said he “just did enough” on Saturday and Sunday to make sure he secured his PDC tour card.He is now preparing for his first event of the year, the Players Championship, which begins on February .Of trying to push on through the next two years, Bain said: “My practice regime is back and I’m on the board a lot more.“Just now it’s between three and five hours a day.“Then I’ve got darts with my local team on a Monday and a Thursday, local comps as well, so that’s all practice as well.“I’m at the Rowantree now, back in Seaton where I grew up, which is better for me.”The world number  added: “If you get off the mark it sets you up for the rest of the year.“It’s just consistency.“I’ve been to events before and played great and the next day been atrocious.”

title: marian travels back to the hollow mountain
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsMy book about the project, Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain, was published to coincide with the th anniversary of its opening. Invited to join Cameron up at the Cruachan dam for the second of his two recent programmes, I was delighted to tramp the mighty mountain with Scotland’s Number one authority on outdoor pursuits.As an author and broadcaster, Cameron always has an eye on a good story, and so as well as asking me about the lack of health and safety regulations at the time the hydro project was being built, he also wanted to knowthere really was a murder during the construction. There was, as I told him, a body – but the body wasn’t identied, no arrests were made, no court case took place.It would be a shamethat construction period went down in history as an invasion of , workmen – #Tunnel Tigers# as they were dubbed – into one of Argyll#s most beautul settings and a possible murder.My book was intended to give the story of the local people whose lives were punctuated by this ambitious construction project. Quite rightly, those Tunnel Tigers had been lauded in a number of publications. The work that was done hollowing out Argyll’s highest mountain to provide electricity for the nation was amazing.The plan for Cruachan – as for the other major hydro projects of the post World War II era – was conceived by Tom Johnston, to whom I dedicated my book. Johnston was a politician who remained true to his ideals of bringing rural Scotland into the modern world. There was no power in the Highlands, and without power there could be no industry and no prosperity. The engineering genius was Sir Edward MacColl, whose biographer Norrie Fraser called him #a maker of modern Scotland#.Cruachan was the first reversible pumped-storage system in the world. During its years of construction from  to , eminent international engineers visited the project to see how the water was pumped between two reservoirs through reversible turbine generators. At off-peak hours, the water was – is # pumped back up to the reservoir you see high up in the corrie above Loch Awe, held back by a dam that is now so much a part of our landscape. The loch itself is the lower reservoir.I had imagined that the scale of such a project – using Scotland’s top engineering companies who shipped in workers from other parts of the UK and Europe – would have been a cause for resentment and protest by local people.That, of course, failed to take account of the vision of the folk of Dalmally, Lochawe, and Taynuilt. Although it took men with engineering experience to blast the  miles of tunnels, hollow out the mountain itself, and construct the dam, there was also a need for a support army. There were clerks and porters, joiners and caterers, folk willing to let out a room, a caravan, a house, serve in a pub where just occasionally it was necessary to keep a baseball bat behind the bar to maintain bonhomie. The project kick started careers, fortunes and marriages, and gave the area good roads and a tourist industry.If you haven’t visited the hollow mountain or walked Cruachan’s slopes, make  the year you do.[In bold please] Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain is available from the Argyll Book Centre in Lochgilphead and all good book shops, along with Marian Pallister#s other books of local interest.PICS:The Pass of Brander before work started. no_aCruachanLe before the project # the Loch Awe Hotel with steamers. no_aCruachanThe Queen opening the project in October . no_aCruachanWorking on the  miles of tunnels. no_aCruachanWorking on the road to the dam, overlooking Loch Awe. no_aCruachan

title: coleman and aliyev impress ardrishaig
story: Robert LaceyUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs the lights dimmed in Ardrishaig Hall on Saturday January , and the audience chatter subsided, two young men, dressed entirely in black, strode into view.Jâms Coleman sat at the splendid Yamaha grand piano that for all visiting musicians must be such a relief to see, while Jamal Aliyev carefully set the spike of his special Giovanni Gabrielli Cello , an instrument re-discovered after a -year absence from public performance.Then the music began and the dark first notes of Beethoven’s Cello and Piano Sonata op. no. in G minor filled the hall. It was written for Count Friedrich Wilhelm, supposedly simplied for amateurs to play. However, Jamal and Jâms being master musicians showed the power of this often disregarded piece, to be immense. One of the first works to make piano and cello equal musical partners, it is full of ingenious dialogue between the instruments. The structure is unusual, but with such expert performers it delighted the audience who were moved by every turn and twist of this deeply emotional work.Jâms, from North Wales, after remarking on the three ferry crossings required to get to Ardrishaig via Bute, introduced the next piece, Ernest Bloch’s work ‘From Jewish Le’. In a style close to Jamal’s heart and heritage, having been born in Baku Azerbaijan, its three elements, ‘Prayer’, ‘Supplication’ and ‘Jewish Song’, are full of the pathos and sorrow felt by the Jewish nation and also full of the signature augmented intervals and minor key tonality of much of middle eastern musics. How beautully these pieces demonstrated the lyrical qualities of the cello. Jamal’s bow searched for all possible nuances of tone and dynamic as his instrument sang from its lowest notes to a seductive soprano register.The concert continued after the interval with a second Beethoven work. The audience may have noticed a minor kerfuffle at the piano as many pages were rapidly turned before starting. Would it be the ‘Seven Variations’ for cello and piano or the ‘Twelve’, both based on themes from Mozart’s Magic Flute  The ‘Seven Variations’ won, being on the theme from the ‘Pamina’ and ‘Papageno’ duet entitled ‘In men, who know the feeling of love’. This work exhibits Beethoven’s practised ingenuity in the iation form and brought a lighter mood to the programme.Jâms Coleman introduced the final work, Frank Bridge’s Cello Sonata. He told of the four years of torment for the composer as he struggled to express his feelings about the First World War, finally finishing the composition in . The adagio in the piece caused the composer the most dficulty as he struggled with ambivalence about his own pacist views. Jâms and Jamal dealt with the challenges of this complex work which tracks huge changes in the world of music composition that were under way at that time. Again, the lyrical powers of the cello came to the fore as did the virtuosic requirements heaped on the pianist. Despite its undoubted innovations, this piece generously reaches out to its audience. Bridge uses the new musical freedoms only when justied, being happy toto more traditional tonal stability in the lyrical sections.Fulfilled, but not overburdened by the weightiness of the final piece, the audience applauded Jamal and Jâms back to the concert room to perform the ‘Swan’ from Saint-Saens ‘Carnival of the Animals’ as encore. This piece so beautully confirmed the excellence of Jamal’s playing and the superb quality of his quite special instrument.PIC:Jamal Aliyev and Jâms Coleman. no_aJamalandJam

title: over to you inveraray as projects make progress
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowChairman Derrick Anstee opened the latest meeting of Inveraray#s community company bemoaning the loss of local amenities since he first visited the area  years ago.From banks to police station and pier to tourist office, all these things have gone.It was the job of Inspire Inveraray, said Mr Anstee, to #do something about the decline in this town#.Around  people attended the Nicoll Hall to hear an update on projects being pursued by Inspire Inveraray # involving the community hall, Inveraray Pier and even the acquisition of a phonebox.The Architectural Heritage Fund, assisted by a grant from the An Suidhe wind farm community fund  has allowed a structural engineer#s report to be completed on the community hall. In summary, Mr Anstee explained, not a lot had changed since an earlier report, though a lot of remedial work would be needed.Mr Anstee added that the question is: #What use to people want to make of the hall  Do we need it at all #The next question is whether the hall should be demolished and a new facility built or whether the facade should be retained # for which heritage grant funding may be available. A sense of frustration was evident in the hall as people heard about surveys and consultation # a familiar theme for Inspire Inveraray since its formation three years ago.Hotelier Donald Clark clearly wants to see action and is not keen on retaining the old building. He said: #It#s an eyesore. I think we need to work on the premise of demolition then decide on the use of it.#Next it was on to the vexed question of Inveraray Pier. Numerous attempts to start a dialogue with the owner Archie MacArthur had failed, said Mr Anstee.One approach Inspire Inveraray is looking at is to attempt to purchase the pier using community Right to Buy legislation. There is also the question of whether to bid for the puffer, which Mr MacArthur is trying to sell, as well as the pier itself.To get to the bottom of the community#s views, consultant Charlotte Lee has been employed to pull together opinions and draw up a community action plan.Of only slightly lesser importance is the telephone box in Church Square, in which Inspire Inveraray has expressed an interest. If BT agrees to hand it over, the next question is what to do with it.The many questions highlighted during the evening in connection with the community centre, pier and even the phonebox will be condensed into a straightforward questionnaire to be handed round Inveraray homes with the help of Inveraray Community Council.Anyone wishing to contribute their views or help with the consultation can contact Charlotte Lee on info@cslconsultancy.net or call  .
