But we all know where that ends up.ldquoBase metal doesnrsquot turn to gold, Brexit isnrsquot going to turn into anything less than an unmitigated disaster ndash regardless of any imagined deal which provides all the benefits of the single market with none of the obligations.ldquoThe UK faces an unprecedented political crisis and the only people who can get us out of this mess are the people by voting again.ldquoFailure by the politicians means people must now take back control of our destinies.Also on the  was Catherine Stihler MEP, who is standing down from her position before Brexit and the next election to join a data-sharing initiative.The Labour representative said: ldquoThe first thing I ever worked upon was to battle labelling, to put graphic warnings on cigarette packets.ldquoYou might not think thatrsquos a big issue but when you think about the fact we could regulate at a European level over  million people to create one rule rather than - dferent countries, you could never have done thatit hadnrsquot been for us working together.ldquoI feel very proud that I instigated that and wersquove led in Scotland with tobacco legislation. We also didnrsquot have braille on pharmaceutical packaging. People from the industry saidit hadnrsquot been for that amendment or work we would never have done it. That makes such a dference across the whole of the EU.ldquoI hope the future of the EU is that we will still be members and that each one of you will help us will help us together.

title: one-in-20-does-not-believe-holocaust-took-place
story: Almost two-thirds of respondentseither could not say how many Jews were murdered or ldquogrossly under-estimated the number, a survey of more than , people by the Holocaust Memorial Day Trustfound.On Sunday, hundreds of thousands of people, including survivors, politicians and members of the public, will gather to mark Holocaust Memorial Day and remember its six million Jewish victims.More than , activities are expected to take place, while ceremonies will be held in London, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.A national commemorative ceremony will take place in Westminster to mark the day, which is also acknowledging the th anniversary of the genocide in Rwanda and  years since the end of the genocide in Cambodia.Holocaust survivor Steven Frank, who was one of  children who survived the Theresienstadt camp in Czechoslovakia along with his two brothers, said the figures were ldquoterribly worrying.His father, who helped hide Jews as part of the Dutch Resistance, was arrested in Amsterdam and taken to Auschwitz in Nazi-occupied Poland, where he was gassed on January  .Mr Frank, , said he was ldquosurprised that the survey found as many as one in  people still did not believe the Holocaust took place.He said: ldquoIn my experience, people donrsquot have a solid understanding of what happened during the Holocaust and thatrsquos one of the reasons I am so committed to sharing what happened to me.ldquoAt one of my talks, I met someone who said the Holocaust didnrsquot happen. The only way to fight this kind of denial and anti-Semitism is with the truth ndash I tell people what happened, what I saw and what I experienced.ldquoEducation is so important. If we ignore the past, I fear history will repeat itself.HMDT chief executive Olivia Marks-Woldman said: ldquoThe Holocaust threatened the fabric of civilisation and has implications for us all. Such widespread ignorance and even denial is shocking.ldquoWithout a basic understanding of this recent history, we are in danger of failing to learn where a lack of respect for dference and hostility to others can ultimately lead.ldquoWith a rise in reported hate crime in the UK and ongoing international conflicts with a risk of genocide, our world can feel fragile and vulnerable. We cannot be complacent.Karen Pollock, chief executive of the Holocaust Educational Trust, said: ldquoWe know that education is vital in the fight against ignorance and hate.ldquoWhatever the statistics, one person questioning the truth of the Holocaust is one too many and so it is up to us to redouble our efforts to ensure future generations know that it did happen and become witnesses to one of the darkest episodes in our history.Communities Secretary James Brokenshire, who will be speaking at Sundayrsquos event, said: ldquoIt remains essential now as ever to remember the Holocaust, to understand why it happened and to learn the stark lessons it gives.ldquoWe must never forget where hatred and bigotry can lead.He added: ldquoThis Government is clear that anti-Semitism has no place in our society and we all have a role to play in confronting hatred and extremism whenever and wherever it occurs.

title: snp-to-table-amendment-to-stop-the-clock-on-brexit
story: MPs have been tabling amendments in Parliament to Theresa Mayrsquos deal, which was rejected at Westminster by an overwhelming  votes earlier this month.SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford is to table an amendment on Monday calling on Mrs May to note the Scottish Parliament, Welsh Assembly and Commons all voted ldquooverwhelmingly to reject her deal.It will also seek an extension to Article  ndash the mechanism which triggered the process of the UKrsquos withdrawal from the EU ndash call for a no-deal Brexit to be ruled out, and demand that Scotland should not be taken out of the EU ldquoagainst its will.The SNP said its MPs will also back the amendments tabled by Labourrsquos Yvette Cooper and Conservative former attorney general Dominic Grieve.Mr Grieversquos would give MPs powers to take control of the parliamentary agenda on a series of days in the run-up to the official date of EU withdrawal on March  to pass resolutions on the way ahead.A cross-party group of MPs, including Ms Cooper and Tory former minister Nick Boles, is seeking to give time for a Bill to suspend the Article  withdrawal processthere is no new deal with Brussels by the end of February.Mr Blackford said: ldquoWith just a matter of weeks before the Brexit date, the Prime Minister must change coursebefore it is too late.ldquoThe Tories think they can do anything they like to Scotland and get away with it, but in this crucial week the wishes of the people of Scotland must not be ignored.ldquoIf, as the Prime Minister claims, the UK is a partnership of equals, then she must stop putting the interests of the right-wing of her party ahead of the interests of the people of Scotland.ldquoTo protect jobs and living standards we need to stop the clock on Brexit and the Prime Minister must stop threatening the disaster of no deal.A UK Government spokeswoman said: ldquolrmWe are leaving the EU on March . The choice is between a deal or no-deal. Itrsquos time for all MPs to get behind the Prime Ministerrsquos deal and avoid a no-deal.ldquoWe are engaging extensively with businesses and people in Scotland, as well as with the Scottish Government.The amendments will be voted on by MPs on Tuesday.

title: vicky-allan-lets-not-forget-the-horrors-of-the-present-as-we-remember-the-past
story: One of the sadnesses of marking this day is that it, in many ways, is not just a piece of distant history. Even once all these Nazi genocide survivors have died, the day will not lose its living voice. For genocide still pulses across the world.The living voice of International Holocaust Remembrance Day is there in the survivors of the many genocides that have happened in recent decades. No other recent genocide may have taken so many lives, but all have been as horrying and bewildering in their atrocity.Many of these voices are still young. Among them, for instance, visiting Scotland this weekend is -year-old Fareeda Abbas, a Yazidi woman who, like Nadia Murad, last yearrsquos winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, is a survivor from Kojo, a village massacred by Islamic State.On August , , Islamic State soldiers gathered all of the people from her village in the school building and asked them to convert to Islam ndash then, when they rejected that, they began killing the men,  over the course of one day, including her father and two of her brothers.For four months, Abbas was held in captivity, raped, beaten, forced to watch an eight-year-old girl being raped. At one point her injuries were so bad she could hardly move or see. After several attempts at escape, on the third she succeeded.Abbas is one of the key driving forces in Yazda, a charity that aims to prevent future genocides against the Yazidi community and other minorities, and to assist them in recovery. Recently it held a fundraiser in Edinburgh, organised by a Scot who had been affected by their story. It was a reminder that the Yazidi plight must not be forgotten.Thousands of Yazidi women are still imprisoned by Isis. Around , Yazidi were killed, and many more fled to refugee camps. It is a community so broken its survival depends on international support.Meanwhile, there are the voices of the Rohingya, around , of whom were killed in Myanmar in , and , are currently living across camps in Coxrsquos Bazar.There is also Sudan, where hundreds of thousands of Darfuris have been killed under Omar al-Bashirrsquos genocidal regime, and the many other countries, where according to Genocide Watch, there is a genocide emergency.But genocide doesnrsquot pop up from nowhere. We can see it coming. The Genocide Watch site lists around  countries which are already at what it describes as the ldquoextermination stage of genocide, and many more that are involved in polarisation or other processes which it outlines as leading up to mass murder.Never again, we say. But then we look around the word and see that here it is again, and again. If we want to know what wersquove learned in the  years since Auschwitz-Birkenau was liberated, we need only look at how we have reacted to these recent genocides and what the international community has failed to do. These are the people we should think about most on International Holocaust Memorial Day ndash the people still in the grip of horror, or aftermath, the people who need support.Above all, though, this day should provide fuel to a fight against the hatred, polarisation and dehumanisation that, according to Genocide Watch, are preconditions for genocide. These are as present as ever across the world, perhaps on the rise.In this climate, it seems that more than ever we need to listen to the words of Nazi death march survivor Harry Spiro: ldquoI came to the conclusion a long time ago that hating people doesnrsquot achieve anything. People are capable of doing horrendous things to each other, but that isnrsquot overcome by yet more hate.Sharing in mob justiceYou only have to look at some of the responses online to the fact that former Shameless star Tina Malone is being prosecuted for contempt of court for sharing an image of someone said to be Jon Venables to realise that vigilantism is alive and well in the British public. For, it seems that plenty are out to support Malone, not just because they think the possibility of her being jailed is ridiculous and would represent a step too far ndash which is fair enough ndash but because they think she was quite right to share the Venables picture and that he should indeed be exposed.Mob justice seemed to be the mood of the day, with a general feeling pervading that Venables would deserve whatever came to him. Few were the voices saying, this is the law and the kind of restrictions we need in order to live in a civilised society where justice isnrsquot meted out by crowds baying for blood. But Malones fame makes her a particularly good example to pursue for this sharing, which was done by many others.The trial no doubt will gain much attention. Surely, after this, no one will be able to share Venablersquos identity, and say, as she did, ldquoI am not au fait with the law.

title: john-kerr-on-brexit-scotland-and-the-far-right
story: The -year-old Glaswegian is scathing of the way Britain handled the negotiations - and this is a man who knows about negotiation. As a key member of the European Convention, Kerr wrote Article  of the Lisbon Treaty ndash the clause which triggered Brexit. He was permanent undersecretary at the Foreign Office ndash making him effectively the UKrsquos chief diplomat - and he was also our man in Washington and Brussels, serving as Ambassador to the United States and as the British representative to the European Union. He also negotiated the Maastricht Treaty with John Major, securing the UKrsquos opt out from the euro, and negotiated nuclear armaments for Margaret Thatcher at Nato.THE MISTAKES"We didnrsquot know our foe very well," he says of the negotiations ndash not that Kerr sees the EU as an enemy, quite the opposite. "We didnrsquot study the other side. We thought we could have our cake and eat it. We thought they needed us more than we needed them, that we could pick them off one by one, that the deal could be done in Berlin over a weekend."He speaks incredulously of Brexiteer ministers who "didnrsquot understand that [the  EU member states] would stick together, would stick up for Ireland, would defend the integrity of the single market. These were basic mistakes".A bigger mistake, though, was that "we didnrsquot have a clear vision of where we wanted to end up. We didnrsquot decide how close or far away from the EU we wanted to be". Theresa May, says Kerr, avoided that discussion in Cabinet as ministers would have disagreed ndashuntil at Chequers last July when she did put forward her proposals resulting in the resignations of David Davis and Boris Johnson, as Brexit Secretary and Foreign Secretary.Kerr continues with his withering assessment of May: "She didnrsquot reach out to Parliament, shersquos never tried talking to the opposition to find a common position, shersquos never reached out to the country and explained we canrsquot have our cake and eat it, and shersquos never reached out to Edinburgh, Cardf and Belfast and tried to form a consensus of the four nations."It was "muddling along", he says. "Getting involved in tactical battles without an overall strategy is a big mistake ndash and one that we made."If therersquos been worse negotiations in history, then Kerr "canrsquot think of one at the moment". Mayrsquos deal is "very humiliating" and its parliamentary defeat "unprecedented", he says. "With some of my friends in Brussels, itrsquos quite awkward talking to them now as theyrsquore embarrassed by the scale of their success and our humiliation".Kerr believes civil servants from the Foreign Office should have played a central role in negotiations. He turns his attention to Johnson, Davis and Liam Fox, the International Trade Secretary. "I donrsquot think it was a good idea to put Johnson, Fox and Davis in charge of this negotiation," he says. "I think that meant the Prime Minister was slightly cut off from official advice."In comparison, EU officials involved in negotiations "were professionals who knew the European institutions very well". Kerr says the Foreign Office was cut out as it "was not really trusted because it was seen as having been in the past rather in favour of remaining in the EU"."A very serious mistake was made putting Mr Johnson in charge of the Foreign Office," he adds, "because the Prime Minister clearly didnrsquot trust Mr Johnson, but advice coming from the Foreign Office obviously had to come through Mr Johnson and that probably reduces the chances of that advice being listened to."Kerr points out that "the unity of the  has been remarkable, and thatrsquos partly down to us making it easier for them by never coming forward with any proposals at any stage of the negotiation. We always reacted to proposals from the other side. In negotiation, the power of holding the pen is real ndashyou set the agenda by putting forward the proposals, you donrsquot necessarily get everything you put forward but yoursquore off to a good start. The inability to decide in Cabinet where we wanted to end up meant we never actually put a proposal on the table. We made speeches in London but we didnrsquot put forward any negotiating documents."WHAT NEXTKerr now believes that we are heading "for extra time" ndash which could only be done through an extension of Article  delaying Brexit ndash and then a second referendum."I think the muddle wersquore in now is one which canrsquot be sorted by March . I think it may well end up in a second referendum, and I think it should end up in a second referendum as itrsquos now been established that a lot of the promises made in  canrsquot be kept, and people have tumbled to the fact that leaving without a deal would be a very serious economic disruption. Therersquos also been a very clear rejection of the deal that Mrs May brought back. It follows there should either be a better deal or no Brexit. I think wersquore probably heading for a second referendum."Renegotiation is unlikely. "Itrsquos possible a dferent form of Brexit will emerge from Parliament and be negotiated with the EU," says Kerr, "but I donrsquot think so. I think the EU isnrsquot going to make many changes to the deal it spent two years negotiating."As to how a second referendum would go, Kerr says we are in the lap of the gods. "At present, opinion polls say thattherersquos a referendum tomorrow Remainers would win - but David Cameron was ahead with his remain campaign at the start of the  referendum and he lost."If he was advising the Government hersquod tell them "wersquore in a bad mess, the best thing to do is stop and think and ask the people what they want now they can see what leaving means: do they want Mrs Mayrsquos deal, no deal ndash which would be a complete disaster ndash or do they want to stick with the deal wersquove got, full membership of the EU".If Britain chose to remain in Europe "no-one could make us pay a price by taking off our rebate or forcing us to join the euro. These threats the leavers talk about, none of them are true. We would pay no price, political or financial,we decided to stay. So I think wersquore heading for a pause for thought, an extension of Article , and a referendum."SCOTTISH INDEPENDENCEKerr got involved in the independence referendum because of Europe. "I campaigned against Alex Salmond as I didnrsquot believe him when he saidwe Scots went independent while the UK was in the EU that wersquod be allowed to just pull up another chair at the table," he says.Kerr argued that an independent Scotland would need to apply for EU membership. "I thought that would be perfectly doable, but when Scotland got in it would be on new members terms," he said ndash that would mean no UK-style rebate. "Scots would therefore be paying more per head that any Englishman," said Kerr.However, Kerr accepts that "this argument is irrelevant"the UK leaves the EU ndash and that means a big part of the Better Together case collapses.Nevertheless, Kerr remains a strong supporter of the union. "Being members of the UK multiples Scottish influence. If we Scots left the UK, the economic disruption would be even greater than the economic disruptionas members of the UK we leave the EU." He adds: "Economists say the effect of leaving the single market of the UK, in terms of the damage to the Scottish economy, would be five times as great as the damage to the UK of leaving the EU."Personally, Kerr says, he wants to be "very Scottish, pretty British, and rather European".NORTHERN IRELANDKerr is hoping that peace holds in Northern Ireland amid the destabilisation of Brexit. "Wersquore in a very dangerous country when wersquove stories like the Government thinking of going for some amendment to the Good Friday Agreement as a way of getting around the need for the backstop," he says."The Good Friday Agreement is a hugely important achievement and for  years itrsquos worked and we havenrsquot had ato the Troubles. We need to tip toe around this very carefully and Irsquom not sure all the politicians in London quite understand how fragile the situation is."I think itrsquos also a pity that the Government is relying for its majority on the DUP. I think itrsquos quite hard to play the role that John Major and Tony Blair played of being the mediator, the honest broker,yoursquore relying for your political survival on the support of one party which is very sectarian in its support."THE FAR RIGHTKerr says that a second referendum would "bring some social tensions" with hardcore Leavers angry at another vote, but he feels "the social tensions over time of dragging us out of the EU without giving us the chance to say what we want, now the terms are known, would be even more socially disruptive"."Young people," he says, "would be deeply resentfulthe golden oldies refused them the chance to have another say."Kerr also worries about the effect of English nationalism on the rest of the country. "Itrsquos the case that in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, that to be dragged out because of an English nationalist vote against the EU would breed resentment unless there was another fair test of what the public as a whole wants.""You get social tension either way," he says. However, we need to face down the worst of it."If you look at the history of countries where right-wing populist movements gained force ndash say, the history of s Germany ndash the unwillingness to stand up to thugs, thatrsquos really very dangerous to society. The worst reason for not having a second referendum would bewe were frightened of right-wing populist gangs in the street ndash you have to take a stand against that sort of thing. We live in a liberal democratic country and people should not be blackmailed or bludgeoned into a particular political course by threats from thugs."WHAT THE WORLD MAKES OF IT ALLKerr knows the corridors of power the world over. Today, governments around the globe are bewildered by the UK chucking away influence and prestige."The world doesnrsquot quite understand whatrsquos going on," he says. "It seems to be some breakdown in the UK." He adds: "The fact we were one of the two most influential states in the EU meant that American presidents listened to us quite a lot as they knewthey could do a deal with us we could probably sell that deal to the EU. It was a multiplier of our influence."We were more powerful in Brussels as we were known to be influential in Washington, and we were more influential in Washington as were known to be powerful in Brussels. Our friends in Canberra, Delhi, and Ottawa attached considerable importance to the help we could give them in Brussels, so our friends around the world are a bit confused as to why we would want to give all that up."I donrsquot think the die is yet cast, though. I think we could well draw back ndash in which case this would be seen as a very odd episode, where we seem to have gone through some sort of crisis but come through it okay."If we go ahead and leave the EU I think wersquoll pay a price that wonrsquot just be economic ndash and itrsquoll be a serious economic price, particularly for poorer people in our society ndash it would also be political. I think our influence in the world as a whole would shrink."THE ROOTS OF BREXITFew,any, of the main drivers of Brexit had much to do with Europe, in Kerrrsquos opinion. First and foremost is "the way the British political machine and successive governments tended to connive with Fleet Street in presenting Brussels as a place of endless battles and ambushes, that Britain was alone against these horrible continentals".In fact, he says, "we were the most influential state in Brussels. We had more influence on the commission than any other member state, the single market was ised by Margaret Thatcher ndash but ministers liked to pretend that it was a struggle between the forces of light, the British, and the forces of darkness on the continent".Secondly, comes the toxic subject of immigration. "Political elites underestimated the effects of immigration on particular bits of the country. Although immigration is very good for the country, it clearly puts strains on health, education and housing in particular areas, and that was ruthlessly exploited by the Leave campaign."Peoplersquos concern wasnrsquot with young people from Poland coming to earn some money and then go home, it was more with immigration from the subcontinent, from India and Pakistan, and there was that nasty link made between Muslim immigration and a terrorist threat ndash a  link in my view."EU membership doesnrsquot in any way restrain what our immigration rules are in respect of non-EU citizens, sopeople had wanted to restrict immigration from the subcontinent they could have done so at any time and the EU would have had nothing to say about it."Finally, therersquos the economic component. "The huge wealth of financial Britain, particularly the City of London, contrasted with some left behind bits of the country, and that contrast was deepened by the austerity policies of George Osborne."Saying lsquowe are all in this togetherrsquo sounded good but it didnrsquot feel like that for people who saw tax cuts for the rich and huge cuts in support for local government, the NHS, education, and the closure of libraries. That too had nothing to do with the EU. It wasnrsquot EU rules which meant we had to go through austerity, it was the decision after the  crisis that we needed to tighten our belts, and the way we tightened our belt was seen in some parts of the country as pretty unfair."Itrsquos a pity then, Kerr adds wryly, that the standard bearers for the remain campaign in  ended up being David Cameron and George Osborne.

title: why-venezuela-is-the-one-to-watch
story: THE rousing lyrics of the national anthem said it all. ldquoOff with the chains! Off with the chains!, they sang as one voice in the streets of Caracas last Wednesday. Just moments earlier, constitution in hand, Juan Guaido, standing before tens of thousands of his supporters had taken the oath declaring himself president of Venezuela.No sooner had he done so than news broke of the United Statesrsquo recognition of Guaido as the interim president and a short time later a whole raft of Latin American countries, notably allies of Washington, duly followed suit.It all might have had a feeling of spontaneity, but watching the dramatic events unfold last week in Venezuela one was left with the persistent impression that so much of what was unfolding was all very carefully orchestrated.By Friday, in a leafy square in the Caracas neighbourhood of Chacao, Guaido ndash now the de facto opposition leader to incumbent president Nicolas Maduro ndash was urging Venezuelarsquos armed forces to ldquocome over to the side of the people to bring about fresh elections and ato democracy.As every day passes the distinct whf of regime change becomes ever stronger in Venezuela, leaving this giant Latin American country at an uncertain political crossroads and one not without some considerable danger.Even the timing of last weekrsquos resurgence in the countryrsquos opposition to Maduro seemed to have been worked out to the day. It came during a highly symbolic date for Venezuelans, as they marked the st anniversary of a civilian and military uprising that overthrew former Venezuelan dictator General Marcos Perez Jimenez back in .So is history repeating itself and is Maduro, widely regarded as a dictator, about to be ousted, or will he, as some suggest, hang on with the help of the countryrsquos all-powerful military Venezuelarsquos journey to this volatile political juncture has been a rocky one to say the least. For his part, Maduro has continued the huge social welfare programmes and price control policies of previous Venezuelan leader Hugo Chavez, who steered the country toward socialism before dying in .But a crash in the price of crude oil in  was the catalyst for Venezuelarsquos woes, with the cost of a barrel dropping from nearly  to . This coincided with nearly a decade of mismanagement, as the countryrsquos government squandered its phenomenal oil wealth. Today, oil production has declined to barely one-third of the level a decade ago.At the same time, inflation has soared, and the International Monetary Fund predicts it will reach a staggering  million per cent this year.The crisis has left Latin America reeling from an unprecedented mass exodus of Venezuelan migrants in search of food. About . million people have fled the crisis since , according to the United Nations, while those among the  million Venezuelans left behind face failing public services including water, electricity and transport.Last week, it seemed like their patience had finally run out, and buoyed by the appearance of a new leader in the shape of telegenic congressional chief Guaido, many seemed ready to face down the Maduro regime.Such a stance, of course, has been music to the ears of those in the US administration of President Donald Trump who have been gunning for Maduro for some time. As far back as the summer of , Trump, citing George HW Bushrsquos - invasion of Panama as a positive precedent, repeatedly pushed his national security staff to launch a military assault on crisis-plagued Venezuela.According to reports in the American weekly magazine The Nation, Trump wanted to know why the United States could simply not invade  Time and again in meetings with senior staff he is said to have brought up the idea.While military and civilian advisers, are said to have forcefully dismissed the notion Trump then outsourced Venezuela policy to Florida Senator Marco Rubio, who, along with National Security adviser John Bolton and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo began co-ordinating with the Venezuelan opposition.Indeed, prior to being appointed Secretary of State, Pompeo, former director of the CIA in , was already on the record as admitting that he wasldquohopeful that there can be a transition in Venezuela.The CIA he said was ldquotrying to help themunderstand the things they might do so that they can get a better outcome for their part of the world and our part of the world.CIA meddling in Latin America, of course, is nothing new, making it easier for Maduro to point the finger at Washington and casting those it supports in Venezuela as nothing more than American puppets.Almost immediately after Washingtonrsquos recognition of Guaido last week Maduro broke off relations with the US, giving its diplomats until this weekend to leave and ordering Venezuelan diplomats tohome by the same deadline. Not surprisingly, Madurorsquos reliable allies in the shape of China, Cuba, Bolivia, and Turkey then rallied in their backing for the president, none more so than Russia.ForCuba was the Kremlinrsquos closest ally in Latin America during the Cold War, these days itrsquos Venezuela, whose still vast oil wealth gives Moscow direct influence over an Opec member.That Madurorsquos predecessor and mentor Chavez was stridently anti-American made Venezuela the ideal partner in the eyes of Russian president Vladimir Putin.According to an investigation by the Reuters news agency, the Kremlin is deeply invested in the survival of Madurorsquos regime, having sunk both political and financial capital into Venezuela. Russia is said to have propped up the countryrsquos rulers with at least  billion in loans and credit lines since , often taking oil assets in . For obvious reasons then Moscow is far from happy about what one Russian official government newspaper described as the US ldquocarrying out a classic coup drsquoetat in Venezuela.According to an exclusive report by Reuters, the contractors are associated with the so-called Wagner group whose members, mostly ex-service personnel, fought clandestinely in support of Russian forces in Syria and Ukraine.The story cites Yevgeny Shabayev, the head of the Khovrino Cossack organisation, who has his own background as a mercenary and routinely speaks to the international press about such activities as well as anonymous sources.ldquoOur people are there directly for his protection, Shabayev told Reuters, adding that the mercenaries were there specically to prevent rogue members of Venezuelarsquos security forces from detaining Maduro. He also claimed that Wagner had around  iniduals in the country.Citing contacts in a Russian state security organisation, Shabayev claims the Russian contingent flew to Venezuela at the start of last week, a few days before opposition protests to Maduro started.He said they set off in two chartered aircraft for Havana, Cuba, from where they transferred onto regular commercial flights to Venezuela. While verying such claims remains dficult, the report,accurate, would underline the extent to which Russia is concerned over the latest development in Venezuela and the potential of the crisis to draw in outside forces.For the moment, most observers agreethat the direction in which the crisis travels in the coming days and the fate of Maduro and his rival Guaido will very much depend on the reaction of Venezuelarsquos own military.Showing considerable astuteness, Guaido has tried to break the strong bonds that tie the army and Maduro by offering an amnesty to any personnel in the ,-strong armed forces who disavow the president.Addressing members of the military last week before renewed street protests, Guaido said: ldquoWersquore not asking you to launch a coup drsquoetat, wersquore not asking you to shoot. Wersquore asking you not to shoot at us.On Friday, at a news conference, he went even further in efforts to appease the army. ldquoI want to insist, to our military family, our brothers, the moment has arrived for you to put yourselves on the side of the constitution, Guaido appealed.Whether the army that is also supported by some . million civilian militiamen listens to Guaidorsquos offers is crucial in determining whether Maduro stays in office or the country makes a peaceful transition of power. Earlier last week, before the streets protests and Guaido declared himself interim president, there was a small uprising on a Caracas military outpost by low-ranking National Guard officers, that some thought might mark the start of a sht in the militaryrsquos position but nothing has followed since. But not all are convinced.ldquoA sergeant at a National Guard outpost is not to me important, what would be important is a situation like that in a major unit or a battalion, observed Rocio San Miguel, a military expert with non-profit group Citizen Control, speaking of the uprising. In the main, opinions of analysts on which way the armed forces will jumpat all remain mixed. Some suggest there are subtle indications they may, for the first time, be reconsidering their ironclad support for Maduro.ldquoWhat I think we are seeing is a security system and armed forces that are still trying to figure out where they are on this issue, William Brownfield, a former US ambassador to Venezuela, told the Washington Post on Friday.The point on which most analysts agree, however, is that soldiers have multiple reasons to be angry. Military installations are steadily decaying along with the rest of the country, and salaries quickly disappear amid two million per cent annual inflation.Rights organisations say that around  soldiers were arrested in  for conspiring against the government, while , more deserted the National Guard.More than aware of the potential threat that lurks within the military to his government, Maduro has played his own card to keep the army on side, putting officers in charge of key posts in the government and state oil company PDVSA while offering lucrative oilfield services contracts for military-linked firms.So far, over the past week, the armed forces have been unusually restrained in dealing with the political crisis.Not only did they refrain from launching an all-out offensive against massive anti-government demonstrations ndash although  people have been killed in recent days ndash but they have also not arrested Guaido.According to the New York Times, factions of army officers who have already defected say they are plotting s from their makesht headquarters in Peru, Colombia and other neighbouring countries. The Trump administration is also said to have held secret meetings with rebellious Venezuela military officers over the last year to discuss their plans for the overthrow of Maduro, according to American officials and a former Venezuelan military commander who participated in the talks.But not all within Venezuelarsquos militaryrsquos ranks view Washington in a favourable light, far from it. A resilient anti-American ideology remains and in some cases was no doubt inadvertently bolstered last week by Washingtonrsquos eagerness to back Guaido. ldquoThese are guys that fought with Chavez, that believe in their hearts that the US is the enemy, says Eva Golinger, a Venezuelan-American lawyer and author of Confidante Of "Tyrants" who is also an outspoken supporter of the late Venezuelan leader.Sixty years ago, when Venezuelans took to the streets, the then dictatorship collapsed in the face of surging protests.But demonstrations alone didnrsquot bring down Venezuelarsquos strongman back then. Only when the military stepped in, with tanks alongside protesters, did the dictatorship fall. That sobering fact is something that not only ordinary Venezuelans are acutely aware of but also self-declared interim president Juan Guaido and those in Washington who have given him their blessing and support.For that simple historical precedent alone, in the days ahead all eyes will be on Venezuelarsquos army, for itrsquos in their hands that the future political direction of the country almost certainly now lies.

title: future-shock-did-top-secret-pentagon-stargate-letter-convince-senator-john-mccain-alien-invasion-was-imminent
story: Despite its rather outreacute nature, this tale is no urban myth ndash although some details have been embellished over the years. One retelling even has Reagan weeping on Spielbergrsquos shoulder as ET ldquowent home. Having since confirmed the event indeed took place, the legendary director has also admitted he remains unsureReagan was being honest with his guests ndash or simply pulling off deadpan surrealism better than Rikki Fulton or Jacob Rees-Mogg.One thing is incontrovertibly true ndashRonald Reagan had intimate knowledge of extra-terrestrial visitations to Earth, then he certainly knew they werenrsquot friendly, doe-eyed botanists. Without even taking his bizarre satellite-laser ldquoStar Wars missile defence system into consideration, Reaganrsquos numerous mentions of aliens in speeches marked him as a blatant UFO-nut hiding in plain sight. One turning a blind eye to the Pentagon burning through tens of millions of taxpayer dollars investigating ldquoforeign advanced aerospace weapons.Yet,such research ndash carried out under dferent guises by the US military since Project Blue Book in the s ndash was simply to ascertain the threat from traditional Russian or Chinese bogeymen, then it seems they were a wee bit more technologically advanced than previously thought.This week, the Pandorarsquos Box of top secret Pentagon documents was declassied under a Freedom of Information request ndash a single five-page letter containing the titles of a bewildering litany of otherworldly research papers commissioned from scientists around the globe.The titles of these academic studies certainly donrsquot concur with commonly accepted Russian technical malevolence like vote rigging and web trolling. Certainly, research into invisibility cloaking, dark energy, stargates, multidimensional manipulation, meta-materials, laser weapons, quantum entanglement and ldquocontrolling external devices in the absence of limb-operated interfaces seems more like a Philip K Dick fever dream.If nothing , the document ndash addressed primarily to the office of late Senator and former pilot John McCain, who also had a considerable interest in colourful accounts of unusual aviation ndash certainly proves the Pentagon had been trying to get their heads around the true nature of a somewhat peculiar security threat. And unless the Russians or Chinese have torn a wormhole through the fabric of spacetime with a laser weapon recently, it wasnrsquot them.Uni lateral thinkingTHE exotic nature of some of the research papers commissioned by the US militaryrsquos Advanced Aerospace Threat Identication Programwould raise a quizzical eyebrow on even Vladmir Putinrsquos Botox-irrigated deathmask.Itrsquos certainly reaffirmed the suspicions of the global Ufology community, who only learned of the research papers existence last week after the AATIP letter ended up on the desk of Nick Pope, ex-head of the UK Governmentrsquos official UFO research project. Colloquially known as Britianrsquos ldquoFox Mulder, the affable Nick immediately teased true believers on Twitter with some ambiguous speculation, saying: ldquoIt still doesnrsquot give us a definitive answer to whether, as claimed, lsquoforeign advanced aerospace weapon threatsrsquo is coded language for UFOs.Nick would likely call the documentrsquos revelations a solid five on the Rio count ndash a new global ET ldquoRichter scalersquo developed by academics at our very own St Andrews University. It marks global reports of extraterrestrial activity from zero to  ndash the alarm sounding when Jacob Rees-Mogg rips off his skin suit to reveal true reptilian form.Thatrsquos not all academics at St Andrews have been getting up to though. One of the AATIP reportrsquos  ldquoadvanced technology studies was completed by the impressively alpha-sounding Dr Ulf Leonhardt, a respected German scientist working at the uni at the time.Cynics may think Ulfrsquos ldquoInvisibility Cloaking paper better suited to Hogwartsrsquo library than John McCainrsquos desk, but the good professor is a noted global expert on something called quantum optics, which juxtaposes the fact nothing actually exists with photon manipulation. One day, this may potentially allow a military force to enter a country without being seen. And grant perverts access to your bathroom as you shower.Follow the moneyTRUTH is a funny thing ndash will orsquo the wisp, a subjective perception in the beholderrsquos eyes. Yet, as the human brain or internet didnrsquot always exist, an untainted objective reality clearly exists ndash and the empirical truth behind any murky complex mystery involving our species often reveals itself by simply applying one time-tested method ndash following the money. By doing this, the AATIP report is revealed as perhaps less revelatory than hype suggests.From -, the Pentagon spent pound million commissioning these  papers. Meaning, towering piles of hard cash were on offer for academics willing to sell their credibility for a basement swimming pool. Might be dficult to find one who wouldnt. A few imaginative chapters of pseudo-waffle on non-existent technology that only Hollywood CGI can presently bring to le  Beats working for a living.Itrsquos also perhaps no coincidence that many of these ldquoacademics were already already part of a network of true believers ndash the now-defunct ldquoNational Institute for Discovery Science , which was well known for its studies of UFO sightings, extraterrestrials and other ldquofringe topics.To understand why such a band of eccentrics were ever commissioned by the Pentagon in the first place, we must first understand the origins of AATIP. Initiated in  by then US Senator Harry Reid to study unexplained aerial phenomena, the group was formed at the request of Reidrsquos influential friend, Nevada businessman and UFO true believer Robert Bigelow. Who, coincidentally, also founded the aforementioned NIDSci.And, again, entirely coincidentally Irsquom sure, it was Bigelow Aerospace which won the AATIP contract to manage its research.Military writer Joseph Trevithick has since carried out some admirable work uncovering the interesting backgrounds of some of the papers authors, a number of whom already had associations with Bigelow. The largest single source of these Pentagon academic reports is EarthTech International of Texas, whose CEOs both also have close ties to the billionaire business mogul.Trevithick also reveals that Marc Millis, a former NASA propulsion engineer, is also among the authors. Millis apparently left NASA after attending a venture capital event that some fella called Joe Firmage hosted in . Firmage, for those unaware, is a Silicon Valley tech millionaire who claims he had an unexplained visionary experience where a lsquobeingrsquo produced a ball of energy which then entered his body. Weve all been there.Perhaps being exposed to the mind-bending fantasies of some of these academics explains another great mystery of our times ndash why John McCain believed Sarah Palin was a sensible choice of running mate for the  Presidential elections. Likely he thought she would come in handy in a world threatened by extra-terrestrial invasion, being able to communicate directly with destructive, hostile oddities intent on destroying Earth and depleting our natural resources.And finally ...ON his death bed, John McCain enjoyed one last dig at his nemesis Donald Trump, accusing him of ldquohiding behind walls. Although McCain never became president himself, another wall-hating Republican did ndash the aforementioned Ronald Reagan.Although itrsquos unknownthe AATIP paper convinced McCain of a viable alien threat, itrsquos certain that Reagan believed in such a possibility ndash and used his fears as leverage to take down the actual Berlin Wall.During the  Geneva Summit, Reagan and Soviet premier Mikhail Gorbachev had a private chat. Years later, Gorbachev revealed that Reagan had simply asked him to set aside their dferences in case the world was invaded by aliens. No, really.Perhaps, in the current climate of ision, intolerance and social discord, another famous fearmongering speech by Ronnie is still relevant today: ldquoI occasionally think how quickly our dferences would vanishwe were facing an alien threat from outside this world."Yet, I ask you, is not an alien force already among us  What could be more alien to the universal aspirations of our peoples than war and the threat of war Follow Bill on Twitter: @futureshockbb

title: removing-irish-backstop-from-brexit-deal-would-not-be-acceptable-to-eu
story: Simon Coveney said the European Parliament would not raty an agreement without it, adding: ldquoItrsquos as simple as that.It comes as Mrs May faces another crunch week in Westminster as her deal s to the Commons tomorrow, with a number of MPs tabling amendments to try to change the course of Brexit.The Prime Ministerrsquos deal was dramatically defeated by  votes earlier this month, with much of the criticism focused on the backstop ndash a measure aimed at avoiding a hard border on the island of Ireland.Speaking on the BBCrsquos Andrew Marr Show, Mr Coveney said: ldquoThe backstop is already a compromise. It is a series of compromises. It was designed around British red lines.He added: ldquoThe Irish position is, look, we have already agreed to a series of compromises here, and that has resulted in what is proposed in the Withdrawal Agreement.ldquoIreland has the same position as the European Union now, I think, when we say that the backstop as part of the Withdrawal Agreement is part of a balanced package that isnrsquot going to change.He also played down comments by Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar, who said soldiers couldto the borderBrexit goes ldquovery wrong.Health Secretary Matt Hancock denied the comments meant Mrs Mayrsquos Brexit deal was ldquodead in the water.He said: ldquoThatrsquos a negotiating position the Irish are taking, but I think itrsquos also extremely clear from that interview and the tone... Ireland doesnrsquot want to have a no-deal Brexit.Hard-line Brexiters and Northern Irelandrsquos Democratic Unionist Party strongly oppose the backstop, arguing it threatens the integrity of the UK.Tory MP Andrea Jenkyns called on the Prime Minister to abandon the proposals, telling Sky News: ldquoIrsquod like to see her bin the backstop. I think we need to bin it completely.It came as it emerged preparations are being looked at for the possible imposition of martial law after a no-deal Brexit. Sources described the move as the civil service ldquoprepping for all possibilities.Mr Hancock denied the Government was ldquospecically planning for martial law but did not rule it out.He also distanced himself from claims he told colleagues he could not guarantee patients would not die in a no-deal scenario, insisting: ldquoI didnrsquot quite say that. Cabinet discussions are meant to be secret.MPs have been tabling a iety of amendments in a bid to force Mrs May to change tack on Brexit.Labour MP Yvette Cooper, chair of the Home Affairs Select Committee, has lodged plans to extend Article  by up to nine monthsno deal is agreed by the end of February.She told the BBC: ldquoThat is not about blocking Brexit, that is about being responsible and making sure you can get a Brexit deal.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said her party would back the amendment.Meanwhile, Westminsterrsquos influential Exiting the EU Committee, which includes prominent Brexiter Jacob Rees-Mogg, insisted Mrs May must rule out a no-deal exit.Chairman Hilary Benn said: ldquoHaving taken a wide range of evidence on the implications of a no-deal Brexit, the committee is clear this cannot be allowed to happen.The Labour MP added: ldquoMPs must be able to vote on extending Article Parliament cannot reach agreement on a way forward before  March.

title: livingstone-is-fly-tipping-hotspot
story: The Woodland Trust say that Livingston had the biggest problem with large-scale discarded refuse out of more than , sites they looked at across Britain.The problem is so bad trees have had to be cut down because of a fungal infection spread through garden waste - including some which are decades old.In total,  beech and sycamore trees at the Woodland Trustrsquos Dedridge Wood in the West Lothian town are dead or dying from aan outbreak of Phytophthora cambivora.Ten have already been felled, while a further  have been earmarked for the axe. The trees are thought to be around  years old.The Trust say the trees pose a risk to public safety as they may drop limbs as they die.:New campaign aims to tackle fly-tipping in rural ScotlandFully matured trees were felledThe annual bill for clearing up the illegally dumped mess on land the Trust owns across the UK and takes care of was pound, in  - and over the last five years clean-ups have totalled pound. million.Some pound, was spent clearing waste from woods in Livingston. The total would have been even higher had it not been for the efforts of over  volunteers including children who took part in six litter picks removing  skips of waste in total.Phytophthora cambivor is also known to undermine root systems so infected trees can be at risk of toppling completely. They have to be felled to avoid risk to the public in what is a busy area near a school.Once the trees are felled the area will be replanted with native shrub and small tree species that are not susceptible to the infection, including willow, hazel and hawthorn.:One million Scots living in dirty towns as council cuts sees fly-tipping soar#Woodlands are being used for hundreds of incidents of tipping and littering, with waste found ranging from fridge freezers and mattresses to carpeting, the remains of a garden wall and oil drums.In some of the more bizarre incidents, the trust found a bath and even a shrine with a sheeprsquos head.In  there were , separate fly-tipping and littering incidents,  of which occurred in Scottish woodlands, the charity said.The worst region in England was the north, where the trust had to undertake  clean-ups of illegal waste, at a cost of more than pound,.Other blackspots last year were Smithills Estate in Bolton where more than pound, was spent on clearing up mostly fly-tipping, while just over pound, was spent at Hainault, London and almost pound, at Windmill Hill, near Runcorn, Cheshire.The Woodland Trust Scotlandrsquos site manager Jean Frame said yesterday: ldquoIt is heartbreaking that we have to lose much-loved big old trees like this.ldquoWe would appeal to residents to make the flytipping habit history in . Woodland adds so much to the character of the community it would be tragic to lose more of it because of such selfishness.She added: ldquoSadly garden waste is a big problem in Livingston with large amounts of plant cuttings, grass and soil being dumped in our woods each year.This provides an ideal way for disease to move from one site to another. We implore people not to dump garden waste in our woods -- or any other woods.If you see people dumping garden waste in our woods you can report it to the police on  or through Dumb Dumpers.:New Loch Lomond Police Scotland litter clampdown#The Trust manages some  woods across Scotland. New figures released today show that in  it spent pound, on clearing up litter and flytipping at its Scottish woods.Woodland Trust Scotland spokesman George Anderson said: ldquoThat is money we could be spending on planting new woods or working with children to give them an appreciation of nature.As well as garden refuse, dumped items include old Christmas trees, car tyres, carpets, fridges, and filthy mattresses.

title: neil-mackay-lord-kerr-on-the-future-of-brexit
story: The -year-old Glaswegian is scathing of the way Britain handled the negotiations ndash and this is a man who knows about negotiation. As a key member of the European Convention, Kerr wrote Article  of the Lisbon Treaty ndash the clause which triggered Brexit. He was permanent undersecretary at the Foreign Office ndash making him effectively the UKrsquos chief diplomat ndash and he was also our man in Washington and Brussels, serving as ambassador to the United States and as the British representative to the European Union.He also negotiated the Maastricht Treaty with John Major, securing the UKrsquos opt-out from the euro, and negotiated nuclear armaments for Margaret Thatcher at Nato.When the conversation turned to Brexit, this is what he had to say:The mistakesldquoWe didnrsquot know our foe very well, he says of the negotiations ndash not that Kerr sees the EU as an enemy, quite the opposite. ldquoWe didnrsquot study the other side. We thought we could have our cake and eat it. We thought they needed us more than we needed them, that we could pick them off one by one, that the deal could be done in Berlin over a weekend.He speaks incredulously of Brexiteer ministers who ldquodidnrsquot understand that [the  EU member states] would stick together, would stick up for Ireland, would defend the integrity of the single market. These were basic mistakes.A bigger mistake, though, was that ldquowe didnrsquot have a clear vision of where we wanted to end up. We didnrsquot decide how close or far away from the EU we wanted to be. Theresa May, says Kerr, avoided that discussion in Cabinet as ministers would have disagreed ndash until at Chequers last July when she did put forward her proposals resulting in the resignations of David Davis and Boris Johnson, as Brexit Secretary and Foreign Secretary.Kerr continues with his withering assessment of May: ldquoShe didnrsquot reach out to Parliament, shersquos never tried talking to the opposition to find a common position, shersquos never reached out to the country and explained we canrsquot have our cake and eat it, and shersquos never reached out to Edinburgh, Cardf and Belfast and tried to form a consensus of the four nations.It was ldquomuddling along, he says. ldquoGetting involved in tactical battles without an overall strategy is a big mistake ndash and one that we made.If there have been worse negotiations in history, then Kerr ldquocanrsquot think of one at the moment. Mayrsquos deal is ldquovery humiliating and its parliamentary defeat ldquounprecedented, he says. ldquoWith some of my friends in Brussels, itrsquos quite awkward talking to them now as theyrsquore embarrassed by the scale of their success and our humiliation.Kerr believes civil servants from the Foreign Office should have played a central role in negotiations. He turns his attention to Johnson, Davis and Liam Fox, the International Trade Secretary. ldquoI donrsquot think it was a good idea to put Johnson, Fox and Davis in charge of this negotiation, he says. ldquoI think that meant the Prime Minister was slightly cut off from official advice.In comparison, EU officials involved in negotiations ldquowere professionals who knew the European institutions very well. Kerr says the Foreign Office was cut out as it ldquowas not really trusted because it was seen as having been in the past rather in favour of remaining in the EU.ldquoA very serious mistake was made putting Mr Johnson in charge of the Foreign Office, he adds, ldquobecause the Prime Minister clearly didnrsquot trust Mr Johnson, but advice coming from the Foreign Office obviously had to come through Mr Johnson and that probably reduces the chances of that advice being listened to.Kerr points out that ldquothe unity of the  has been remarkable, and thatrsquos partly down to us making it easier for them by never coming forward with any proposals at any stage of the negotiation. We always reacted to proposals from the other side. In negotiation, the power of holding the pen is real ndashyou set the agenda by putting forward the proposals, you donrsquot necessarily get everything you put forward but yoursquore off to a good start. The inability to decide in Cabinet where we wanted to end up meant we never put a proposal on the table. We made speeches in London but we didnrsquot put forward any negotiating documents.What next Kerr now believes that we are heading ldquofor extra time ndash which could only be done through an extension of Article  delaying Brexit ndash and then a second referendum.ldquoI think the muddle wersquore in now is one which canrsquot be sorted by March . I think it may well end up in a second referendum, and I think it should end up in a second referendum as itrsquos now been established that a lot of the promises made in  canrsquot be kept, and people have tumbled to the fact that leaving without a deal would be a very serious economic disruption.ldquoTherersquos also been a very clear rejection of the deal that Mrs May brought back. It follows there should either be a better deal or no Brexit. I think wersquore probably heading for a second referendum.Renegotiation is unlikely. ldquoItrsquos possible a dferent form of Brexit will emerge from Parliament and be negotiated with the EU, says Kerr, ldquobut I donrsquot think so. I think the EU isnrsquot going to make many changes to the deal it spent two years negotiating.As to how a second referendum would go, Kerr says we are in the lap of the gods. ldquoAt present, opinion polls say thattherersquos a referendum tomorrow Remainers would win - but David Cameron was ahead with his remain campaign at the start of the  referendum and he lost.If he was advising the Government hersquod tell them ldquowersquore in a bad mess, the best thing to do is stop and think and ask the people what they want now they can see what leaving means: do they want Mrs Mayrsquos deal, no deal ndash which would be a complete disaster ndash or do they want to stick with the deal wersquove got, full membership of the EU.If Britain chose to remain in Europe ldquono-one could make us pay a price by taking off our rebate or forcing us to join the euro. These threats the leavers talk about, none of them are true. We would pay no price, political or financial,we decided to stay. So I think wersquore heading for a pause for thought, an extension of Article , and a referendum.Scots independenceKerr got involved in the independence referendum because of Europe. ldquoI campaigned against Alex Salmond as I didnrsquot believe him when he saidwe Scots went independent while the UK was in the EU that wersquod be allowed to just pull up another chair at the table, he says.Kerr argued that an independent Scotland would need to apply for EU membership. ldquoI thought that would be perfectly doable, but when Scotland got in it would be on a new memberrsquos terms, he said ndash that would mean no UK-style rebate. ldquoScots would therefore be paying more per head that any Englishman, he said.However, Kerr accepts that ldquothis argument is irrelevantthe UK leaves the EU ndash and that means a big part of the Better Together case collapses.Nevertheless, Kerr remains a strong supporter of the union. ldquoBeing members of the UK multiples Scottish influence. If we left the UK, the economic disruption would be even greater thanas members of the UK we leave the EU.He adds: ldquoEconomists say the effect of leaving the single market of the UK, in terms of the damage to the Scottish economy, would be five times as great as the damage to the UK of leaving the EU.Personally, Kerr says, he wants to be ldquovery Scottish, pretty British, and rather European.Northern IrelandKerr hopes peace holds in Northern Ireland amid the destabilisation of Brexit. ldquoWersquore in a very dangerous country when wersquove stories like the Government thinking of going for some amendment to the Good Friday Agreement as a way of getting around the need for the backstop, he says.ldquoThe Good Friday Agreement is a hugely important achievement and for  years itrsquos worked and we havenrsquot had ato the Troubles. We need to tip-toe around this very carefully and Irsquom not sure all the politicians in London quite understand how fragile the situation is.ldquoItrsquos also a pity that the Government is relying for its majority on the DUP. I think itrsquos quite hard to play the role that John Major and Tony Blair played of being the mediator, the honest broker,yoursquore relying for your political survival on the support of one party which is very sectarian in its support.The far rightKerr says a second referendum would ldquobring some social tensions with hardcore Leavers angry at another vote, but he feels ldquothe social tensions over time of dragging us out of the EU without giving us the chance to say what we want, now the terms are known, would be even more socially disruptive.ldquoYoung people, he says, ldquowould be deeply resentfulthe golden oldies refused them the chance to have another say.Kerr also worries about the effect of English nationalism on the rest of the country. ldquoItrsquos the case that in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, to be dragged out because of an English nationalist vote against the EU would breed resentment unless there was another fair test of what the public as a whole wants.ldquoYou get social tension either way, he says. ldquoHowever, we need to face down the worst of it.ldquoIf you look at the history of countries where right-wing populist movements gained force ndash say, the history of s Germany ndash the unwillingness to stand up to thugs, thatrsquos really very dangerous to society. The worst reason for not having a second referendum would bewe were frightened of right-wing populist gangs in the street ndash you have to take a stand against that sort of thing. We live in a liberal democratic country and people should not be blackmailed or bludgeoned into a particular political course by threats from thugs.World viewKerr knows the corridors of power the world over. Today, governments around the globe are bewildered by the UK chucking away influence and prestige.ldquoThe world doesnrsquot quite understand whatrsquos going on, he says. ldquoIt seems to be some breakdown in the UK. He adds: ldquoThe fact we were one of the two most influential states in the EU meant that American presidents listened to us quite a lot as they knewthey could do a deal with us we could probably sell that deal to the EU. It was a multiplier of our influence.ldquoWe were more powerful in Brussels as we were known to be influential in Washington, and we were more influential in Washington as were known to be powerful in Brussels. Our friends in Canberra, Delhi, and Ottawa attached considerable importance to the help we could give them in Brussels, so our friends around the world are a bit confused as to why we would want to give all that up.ldquoI donrsquot think the die is yet cast, though. I think we could well draw back ndash in which case this would be seen as a very odd episode, where we seem to have gone through some sort of crisis but come through it okay.ldquoIf we go ahead and leave the EU I think wersquoll pay a price that wonrsquot just be economic ndash and it will be a serious economic price, particularly for poorer people in our society ndash it would also be political. I think our influence in the world as a whole would shrink.

title: brexit-theresa-may-urged-to-secure-irish-backstop-concessions-from-eu
story: As the Prime Minister faced another Commons showdown over her EU withdrawal agenda on Tuesday, Downing Street was battling to keep control of the Brexit timetable.:Neil Mackay: Article  author John Kerr says there WILL be another referendumIn a pointed intervention, arch-Brexiteer Boris Johnson insisted he had it from "senior sources" the PM was planning to go to Brussels to renegotiate the backstop and win a "freedom clause".However, Irelands deputy prime minister Simon Coveney insisted there would be no changes to the Withdrawal Agreement which states the UK will obey EU customs rulesno wider deal has been struck after a transition period.Mr Coveney said the backstop was crucial in preventing a hard border.He told the Press Association: "Peace and the Good Friday Agreement are more important than Brexit."Even in a no-deal Brexit situation every party and every MP in the UK will have a responsibility to ensure there is noto a hard border and Northern Ireland is protected."That wont be easy and those who misrepresent the backstop dont have an alternative to it."Mr Coveneys comments were seen as a swipe at Tory Brexiteers hoping to use Commons amendments on Tuesday to try and force a change in direction on the backstop.: SNP to table amendment to lsquostop the clockrsquo on BrexitAttention is focusing on an amendment by Tory grandee Sir Graham Brady which calls for the removal of the backstop and "alternative arrangements" to be put in its place.Brexiteers saythe non-binding amendment is passed it will give the PM more leeway to win concessions from the EU.Sir Graham, who is chairman of the highly influential  Committee of backbench Tory MPs, told the BBC: "My amendment is an attempt to bring the kind of compromise forward that can actually attract the support of a majority of the House of Commons."I hope it will on Tuesday, and demonstrate in terms to the EU that there is a way forward."Meanwhile, pro-Europe amendments pose a threat to Mrs Mays grip on Brexit.The Government is thought to be particularly concerned about a cross-party backed amendment put forward by Labours Yvette Cooper which is aimed at stopping a no-deal exit and paving the way for keeping the UK in the EU until the end of the year.The Dailyreported that the PM is seeking to see off the threat of a Tory rebellion, and the possibility of ministerial resignations, by considering whether to hold a "meaningful vote" on Brexit within the next fortnight.A dozen pro-European ministers including Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd and Justice Secretary David Gauke held a conference call in which they agreed such a move would help defer a potential rebellion, according to the newspaper.Writing in the Daily , Mr Johnson called on the PM publicly to confirm a "change of heart" on the withdrawal deal.He said: "That backstop is dead, rejected by the biggest ever parliamentary majority and that is why I hope and pray that I am right about the intentions of Number ."If we mean it,we really try, I have no doubt that the EU will give us the Freedom Clause we need."Andthe PM secures that change - a proper UK-sized perforation in the fabric of the backstop itself - I have no doubt that she will have the whole country full-throatedly behind her."

title: house plan approved at oldmeldrum
story: The future of Oldmeldrum Golf Club has been secured thanks to councillors at the Formartine Area Committee.Plans to build a single house on land at the golf course went before councillors on Tuesday, January .The site in question is located directly behind an existing house next to the A and A junction.It is currently used for turf growing, but it had been classed as “obsolete” as it is cheaper for the Golf Club to buy new turfcompared to the man hours needed to maintain and cut their own.The planning application received a total of  representations, all of which were in support of the idea.However in a report put to councillors ahead of the meeting, council planners recommended that the plan be refused as the land had never been developed, and that the development itself was contrary to policy in the Aberdeenshire Local Development Plan.Speaking at the meeting on behalf of the club, Patricia Ramsay said that it is currently facing financial dficulties and the debt that it has is preventing the club from moving forward.She added: “The sale of this unused piece of land is the only way of raising much needed funds.“This would be a leline to this community asset.”After discussing the plan, councillor Paul Johnston suggested that the plans be approved with a delegated grant, and his decision was backed by councillor Karen Adam.Cllr Johnston said: “We have to think about the public circumstances, this is a private club but should it have to wind up, that would have a knock-on effect in the local community.”The proposal went to a vote and seven councillors backed the plan with just one vote against it.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: ice cream parlour to go orange for charity
story: Mackie#s of Scotland will colour their most popular flavour, known as #Traditional#, bright orange on Friday, February , to raise awareness and money for charity.Mackie’s ., their Aberdeen ice cream parlour, will be a bright vision with orange lighting, balloons and staff dressed in orange T-shirts for Muscular Dystrophy UK.Even the company’s logo will be converted to an orange spotted cow for the day. Alongside the orange Traditional ice cream, a parlour cabinet will be filled with over  orange tubs, each containing one of nine dferent prizes, from £ gt vouchers, to chocolate bars, so that customers can take part in a fundraising lucky dip.Mackie’s Marketing Director, Karin Hayhow said: “Muscular Dystrophy UK is a charity close to our hearts because we have experienced first-hand the severity of the illness.“We hope that our parlour customers have fun with the orange lucky dip infor a donation towards the work of Muscular Dystrophy UK.”The company is getting behind the day as part of their long-running support for people with any type of muscular dystrophy in Scotland.Muscular Dystrophy UK is the official charity for Mackie’s of Scotland and the joint venture company, Mackie’s at Taypack who make Mackie’s potato crisps and other savoury snacks.The association is founded on the personal experience of both companies, as Denis Emslie who worked as the Sales Director at Mackie’s of Scotland for  years, and Mark Taylor - brother of George Taylor, Managing Director at Mackie’s at Taypack - both lost their lives to forms of MD.Scotland’s Muscular Dystrophy UK Regional Development Manager, Dean Widd said: “We are incredibly grateful to our wonderful corporate partners Mackie’s of Scotland. title: mackie s offers sweet take on burns night scran
story: Back by popular demand, Mackies of Scotland is relaunching its limited edition haggis and marmalade ice cream for Burns Night.The handcrafted speciality recipe – which has been made on the firms Westertown family farm – is available all weekend at Mackie’s . parlour in Aberdeen.The Burns Night treat will be available all weekendAt am this morning, piper Robert Reid from Deeside Caledonia Pipe Band piped the haggis ice cream in to the Marischal Square parlour.The ice cream has been made with Scotland’s famous Hall’s haggis, and has orange marmalade swirled through the mix.In celebration of Scotland’s Ploughman Poet, customers at . will be given free samples of the experimental dessert – and those who play a tune on the bagpipes will be able to enjoy any free scoop of their choice.Yvette Harrison, Parlour Manager at Mackie’s ., said: “While Marmalade is not a traditional accompaniment for Haggis – we added a ripple to help make this Scottish delicacy a little tastier when served cold in ice cream. And, of course a nip of whisky can also be drizzled over the top to raise a cone to the Bard.“Our haggis ice cream was such a hit last year that we just had to bring it back for Burns Night . Since last year’s limited edition batch, we’ve had people visit the parlour specically to try the flavour. So this weekend is the perfect opportunity for those who didn’t get the chance the first time round to satisfy their curiosity – and their taste buds.”Mackie’s is encouraging the public to share their thoughts on the creation with the hashtag #taemackiesicecream.Yvette added: “We love experimenting with our flavours at Mackie’s, and in celebration of Burns we’re challenging everyone to step outside their comfort zone, and try a scoop of our latest creation."data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Brian McKandie"  Pensioners injuries were "worst" Detective had ever seenviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Singer, radio and television presenter Aled Jones MBE will perform a live set at the event"  Charity to mark th anniversary with celebratory Ball viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: top quality entries set to take part in the royal northern spring show
story: Entries are up on the year for next month#s annual multi-breed show and sale of pedigree bulls staged alongside the Royal Northern Spring Show at Thainstone.The sale, to be held on Wednesday, February , has attracted  entries from breeders across the north and north-east, and will include Aberdeen-Angus, Charolais, Limousins, Simmentals, Salers, Herefords, Beef Shorthorns and one British Blue.Last year’s sale saw a top price and a new centre record of ,gns paid for a Simmental bull from the MacPherson family at Blackford, Croy. This was Blackford Hero, by the ,gns Kilbride Farm Double Action, which sold across the water to a breeder in Northern Ireland. The MacPhersons have entered two Simmental bulls for next month’s sale, one of which was bought as a calf at foot from the Deerhurst dispersal and is by the ,gns Blackford Findhorn. The other bull from Blackford is one of the first sons of Blackford Galaxy.At the same sale last year, Charolais bulls produced the second lead price of gns for one from Charles McCombie and family of Auchincrieve, Rothiemay, near Huntly. Tonley has entered three Aberdeen-Angus bulls for this year’s sale.Among the Limousins last year, the overall champion in the pre-sale show from Harry and Lynwen Emslie, Kinknockie, Mintlaw, topped at gns.
